FORM 14
Indian Office

At... Onion Lake, Sask.

August 10th... 1923.

F. H. Paget, Esq.
Ottawa.

Dear Mr. Paget,

The cheques recently sent me for Mr. and Mrs. C. Hebert, school teachers at Cold Lake reserve, were made out for a much larger amount than formerly. They had heard nothing of any increase having been granted them, nor had I. Please let me know if the cheques are O.K. as Mr. and Mrs. Hebert are afraid to spend them although assured by me that everything was right. However, I promised them that I would make sure, and let them know on my next visit.

With kind regards and wishes for your good health.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

Library and Archives Canada / Bibliothèque et Archives Canada
www.collectionscanada.gc.ca
Ottawa, August 20, 1923.

Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 10th instant, with reference to the amount of salary for the June quarter sent to Mr. and Mrs. Hebert, teachers at the Cold Lake Indian day school.

In reply I beg to say that Mr. Hebert was appointed teacher at salary of $650.00 per annum and Mrs. Hebert assistant teacher at salary of $350.00 per annum. They began duties September 5, 1922, and when the return for the quarter ending September 30, 1922, was received, it showed that they had taught 19 days and, as there are 200 teaching days in the school year, Mr. Hebert was paid for that quarter 19/200 of $650.00, or $61.75 and Mrs. Hebert 19/200 of $350.00, or $33.25.

For December quarter each teacher was paid one-fourth of the yearly salary and a like amount was allowed for the March quarter.

When the June quarter return was received, all returns previously received during the last school year, were checked and it was found that from September 5, 1922, to June 30, 1923, they had taught the required number of days, namely, 200, and the balance due to complete their yearly salary was, therefore, paid. The cheques forwarded were correct.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Lang Turner, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Onion Lake, SASK.

Russell T. Perrier,
Supt. of Indian Education.

21, 10, 24
Ottawa, October 21, 1924.

Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of the September quarter return of the Cold Lake Indian Day School.

It is noted that the teacher taught during July, August and September, as he states that he considers it would be preferable to grant the annual two months holidays during the winter than in the summer.

In connection with this I would point out that the Department's approval of this should have been obtained before taking such action. However, as you have signed the return it is presumed that you agree with the teacher and payment is being allowed to him for the three months of July, August and September and two months holidays should be taken during the winter, as the Department can only allow salary for ten teaching months in the present school year, which ends June 30th, next.

Please advise during what month the holidays will be taken at this school.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Russell T. Ferrier,
Supt. of Indian Education.

Lang Turner, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Onion Lake,
H.A.R.C.
Sir,

I have the honour to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of October 21st, last, No. 115-3-3, and in reply to inform you that December 1924 and January 1925 will be the best months to have for holidays at this school and I have arranged with the teacher to close the school for these two months accordingly.

I have the honour to be,
Sir,
Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Indian Agent.

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Form 14
Ottawa, April 22, 1925.

Sir,

As the appropriation from which the bonus to teachers in Indian Day Schools is paid expired promptly on March 31st, last, it was found necessary to draw the bonus cheques previous to the receipt of the quarterly returns from the schools.

Bonus cheques for Mr. and Mrs. Hebert, teachers at the Cold Lake Indian Day School, were drawn for $45.00 each, as it was overlooked that holidays at this school were taken during the month of January and, therefore, were only entitled to receive bonus for two months, or, $30.00 each.

As it is now too late to draw further cheques from the bonus appropriation, it was decided to forward them the cheques already drawn for $45.00 each and to arrange with you to secure a re-fund from them of $30.00. ($15.00 each)

Please secure this sum at the earliest possible date and forward it to the Department under cover of a letter giving this date and file number.

Your obedient servant,

Russell T. Perrier,
Supt. of Indian Education.

Lang Turner, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Onion Lake.
SASK.
Sir:

I have sent my reports on time and I have received no salary for the last quarter ending June 30-1925. I must also say that my wife has received no salary for that term neither.

I remain yours sincerely,

Charles P. Hebert (Indian school teacher)
Le Doff
Alberta

Less 15 cents per month for June 1925 =

Ottawa, September 10, 1925.

WITH CHEQUES.

SIR,

In a letter dated the 31st ultimo, Mr. Chas. Hebert, teacher of the Cold Lake Indian Day School, writes the Department stating that he and his wife have not received their salary cheques for the quarter ending June 30th, last. The reason for this is that the June quarter return from that school has not yet reached the Department. Please arrange with the teacher to forward these to the Department at once.

In order that the teacher may not be inconvenienced any further, the cheques for the amount due to both him and his wife are being enclosed.

Previous to March 31st, last, Mr. Hebert was allowed salary at the rate of $750.00 for the ten teaching months and Mrs. Hebert $350.00, plus bonus of $150.00 in each case. Payment of the bonus to teachers in Indian day schools was discontinued from March 31st, last, but the Department decided to increase the salaries of teachers by $150.00. From April 1st, last, Mr. Hebert's salary is $900.00 for the ten teaching months and Mrs. Hebert's $500.00.

I would refer you to official letter of April 22nd, last, in which you were requested to secure from Mr. and Mrs. Hebert a refund of $15.00 each for overpayment of bonus for the month of January, last. As this amount has not been refunded, it has been decided to deduct the same from the June quarter salary. The following statement shows the balance due both Mr. and Mrs. Hebert, cheques for which amounts are enclosed.

C. Hebert, salary April, May & June, 3/10 of $900 ..$270.00
Less overpayment of bonus for January ..................$15.00

Balance due ........................................$255.00

Mrs. C. Hebert, salary April, May & June, 3/10 of $500 ..$150.00
Less overpayment of bonus for January ..................$15.00

Balance due ........................................$135.00

Your obedient servant,

Lang Turner, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Onion Lake,
SASK.

Russell Ferrier,
Supt. of Indian Education.
Ottawa, November 2, 1925.

Sir:

I am returning herewith the September quarter return of the Cold Lake Indian Day School. The holidays at this school were taken during the months of December, 1924, and January, 1925, and the Department therefore thought that this school would be open during July, August and September of this year. The return, however, states that the school was open only 42 days during the September quarter. Please state what months it was open and furnish any other information that you have available.

I would also refer you to official letter of September 10th, last, in which you were informed that the Department had not received the June quarter return of this school. Please arrange with the teacher to prepare this and you should forward it when sending back the September quarter return.

Enclosure.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]
Russell T. Perrier,
Supt. of Indian Education.

Lang Turner, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Onion Lake, Sask.
Sir,— 

I have the honour to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 2nd instant, No. 115-3-3, and in reply to state that I have seen Mr. C. Hebert, the teacher at the Indian Day School at Cold Lake, and he informs me that owing to sickness in his family he was forced to close the school and to go to British Columbia during the month of July.

As I was at that time away from the Agency, on sick leave, Mr. Hebert stated that he telegraphed to the Indian Commissioner's Office for permission to close the school during the month of July, and received permission on June 26th, last.

With respect to the June returns for this School, it appears from the Office files that this return was mailed - together with that for the Long Lake Indian Day School - on July 30th, last. However, as it appears to have gone astray I am now enclosing a copy, together with the September quarter return.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,
Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent.

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Sir,

I have the honour to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of 24th ultimo No. 427041-15 and to inform you that under separate cover I am writing you the following vouchers:

No. 153 $8.135.00 salary of Field Matron

No. 154 $108.00 rent of School house at Cold Lake.

And that I have handed the two ladies the printed instructions for field matrons which accompanied your letter above acknowledged.

No mention is made in your letter of rent for school house but as it is authorized in your letter dated 10th of January last at the rate of $20.00 per month I now issue the voucher for rent up to the end of November in favour of the resident priest Father Dauphin.

The Field Matron will make a monthly report on her work to this office which in turn I will send to the Department.

I have agreed to a proposition made by the school teacher viz. that the school be closed for the month of January the time to be counted as part of the annual holidays. The attendance had been very small during the few days preceding my visit owing to the severity of the weather and the prevalence of influenza colds on the
Reserve. The attendance is likely to be low during the winter on account of the cold weather and the distance the many of the children have to walk to get to the school being long. I hope the Department will deem it advisable to keep this arrangement but I think it worth trying at least for one year.

Please inform me if the custom with regard to Day school holidays is governed by the Statutes of the Province or if the Department has any special regulation, and I would also ask the Department to send me another copy of instructions for full winter as I have given the one already out & the Rev. Sisters at Cold Lake.

I have the honour to be

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

ORIGINAL ON FILE ...13265-6.

REPORT OF INSPECTOR CRUMBIE ON THE COLD LAKE DAY SCHOOL.

It will be noted that the classroom accommodation is very limited and it is very necessary that class rooms should be enlarged by including part or all of room marked "B" on photo attached. This additional room is now used by the Sisters as a living room. The allowance made to this school is for teacher $400, Assistant and Field Matron $300 and rent of building $240. I would consider present rental ample for rooms required including suggested additional class room accommodation.

Date of Inspection, November 17th, 1917.
Ottawa, February 16th, 1915.

Sir,

In reporting on the Cold Lake school, Inspector Crombie states that the classroom accommodation is limited.

Considering the rent that the Department is paying at this point, sufficient classroom space should be provided.

The Inspector recommends that the room now used as a sitting room be included in the classroom. The Department approves of this suggestion, and you will be good enough to point out to the Sister in charge of this school, the Department's wishes in this matter.

Your obedient servant

J.D. MELANIE
Assistant Deputy and Secretary

Ottawa, April 16th, 1918.

Sir,

Referring to your report of November 17th, 1917, on the Cold Lake day school, I beg to say that the Department wrote to Agent Sibbald, pointing out to him that you considered that the class-room space was very limited.

In replying to this letter, the Agent enclosed a letter which he received from Father Dauphin.

Inspector of Indian Agencies,
Prince Albert, Sask.
Le Joffre 25 March 1918

To Mr. Libby & Co.

Union Lake

April 8th.

Dear Sir,

In answer to your letter of the 4th instant I beg to say that your perfectly willing to have all the first floor of the house arranged for a very close room, but we are much incumbered in doing so.

It is true that the number of pupils enrolled since the opening of the school is a pretty good one, being something about 65 or 70, but the average attendance has very seldom been over 30, while out of these only 20 only come very regularly the whole year round, the other coming just once or twice. The more regular pupils should be kept together so not to mix too many standards and it seems more convenient for the welfare of those more advanced pupils to have different rooms so that one teacher can attend to the backward children while the teacher gives all her attention to the others. Even if the room was large it's just inconvenient to have two teachers in the
Besides teaching proper we are teaching the girls sewing, knitting, weaving etc etc. Whereas the boys are learning to take off their coats for the purpose of the sake of good discipline during this time. We have the boys and girls in the same room for manual work. It would be the utmost disorder without any real benefit could be derived from such teaching as they have not the least idea about these things. So our Sister takes the girls and the Teacher Boys the boys in the school room for cotton, rope and plastering work.

We have to use our own kitchens to prepare the midday meal for the children. If the department should think the rent for three rooms is too high, I can build a school house large enough to have 3 rooms, 2 Class rooms and one kitchen, and supply them with every thing needed which has not been done until now, for we are still using the benches of the Church as seats for the school, and the only two tables have been supplied by the mission.

I hope you will be satisfied with my explanation. Our understanding that we can hardly do any more for two sisters are willing to take care of the child so they can get a greater advantage of their coming to school, it is without a proper education for them.

Yours sincerely,

[Signature]
Sir,

Reference File No. I32985-1, April 16th 1918.

I beg to acknowledge receipt of the above communication regarding Cold Lake Day School. I have read Father Dophin's letter and beg to return same herewith. Notwithstanding what Rev. Father Dophin says regarding class arrangements I am still of the opinion that the rooms must be overcrowded at times, although the ventilation is well looked after by the Sisters.

I do not suppose that it is the intention of the Department to erect any permanent building for school purposes at Cold Lake Reserve, nor would I consider it wise to do so until such time as the Day School proves to be a permanent success. At a comparatively small expense a lean-to addition could be made to the present mission building which would provide the necessary class room accommodation and overcome the possibility of inconveniencing the sisters in their limited quarters.

I have the honour to be, Sir,

Your obedient servant,

Inspector.

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Sir,

I beg to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of 2nd inst., and to enclose herewith my report for the month of April for the Cold Lake Bay school.

After inspecting the school I called upon the Rev. Father Dufresne. He is still very adverse to the change in the class-room which is contemplated. He points out what is very true that the change will inconvenience the Rev. Sisters considerably and also a fact that does not seem to have been taken into consideration before, the pupils are not all the time in the same room as one of the other sisters takes the older girls to a small room leading off the regular class-room for instruction in sewing, knitting and other such work. Should however the Department insist on the change being made he will have it done. Another objection the Rev. Father raised was the disadvantage to having two teachers at work in the same room because if the sitting-room be thrown into the class-room the use of the one used as a sewing-room would have to be discontinued.

Yours Sir,

Sir,

I beg to acknowledge the receipt of the above communication regarding correspondence in connection with Cold Lake Day School.

When making my report upon this school I took into consideration the fact that the pupils were not all the time in the same room, but there is no doubt that part of the time they are and this being the case the room must certainly be overcrowded. There is no doubt that if the class room was enlarged by taking in the adjoining room it would inconvenience the Reverend Sisters considerably and the suggestion made in my letter of April 24th was that a leanto addition be made to the present mission building, which would provide the necessary class room accommodation and overcome the possibility of inconveniencing the sisters in their quarters. If there are no funds available for the erection of a leanto, there, of course, would be nothing else to do but to continue under present conditions, which in my opinion is not altogether satisfactory. An arrangement might be made whereby the Department advance the mission $250 for the purpose of purchasing lumber and erecting an addition to the present building to provide extra class room accommodation, repayment of same to be made by the mission from rent which they are charging the Department at the present time.

Your obedient servant,

Inspector.
Ottawa, June 18, 1915.

Rev. Sir,

In reference to previous correspondence in regard to increasing the class-room accommodation at the Cold Lake Day School, I beg to say that Mr. Inspector Crombie suggests that a leanto addition be made to the present mission building, which would provide the necessary class-room accommodation and overcome the possibility of inconveniencing the sisters in their quarters. The Inspector also suggests that an arrangement might be made whereby the Department could advance the Mission $250.00 for the purpose of purchasing lumber and erecting an addition to the present building to provide extra class-room accommodation, repayment of the same to be made by the mission from rent which they are charging the Department at the present time.

Kindly let the Department know whether you would be willing to carry out the Inspector's suggestion.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

Rev. L. Dauphin,
Legoff, Alta.
Ottawa, June 18, 1918.

Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 5th instant in further reference to increasing the class-room accommodation at the Cold Lake Day School.

In reply I beg to say that the Rev. Father Dauphin is being advised of your suggestion that an arrangement might be made whereby the Department could advance the mission $250.00 for the purpose of purchasing lumber and erecting an addition to the present building to provide extra class-room accommodation; repayment of same to be made by the mission from rent which they are charging the Department at the present time. He is being asked to let the Department know whether they would be willing to carry out this suggestion.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

W. B. Crambie, Esq.,
Inspector of Indian Agencies,
Prince Albert, Sask.

Agent.
With reference to Cold Lake Day School I beg to inform you that I visited the school on 15th inst. and found it closed. I first saw the Rev. Sister Eugenie, who is the teacher. She informed me that after treaty payments the attendance was so bad that she closed the school for Summer holidays on 19th July. Treaty payments took place on 13 & 15th. It is customary at this school to give a months holidays in winter and take it off the summer holidays. A reference to the register showed the wisdom of closing of the school because it showed the average attendance to be 23.50 and for July to the 19th 11.50 showing a considerable reduction.

The room used as a classroom up to the closing of the school, as you are already aware, was much too small for the number of pupils attending, being only 18 x 20. Now an addition is being made which will enlarge the school room to a measurement of 20 x 34 and when completed will be a most satisfactory improvement. The expense of this building is evidently being defrayed by the Roman Catholic authorities respecting which there seems to have been some correspondence between the Department and the Authorities, according to information given me by the Priest at the Mission, the Rev Father Dauphin.

This school so far has been a success and is worthy of being properly furnished. The present furniture consists of only three roughly made desks several forms. The teacher asks me to requisition for 4 No. 3, 8 No. 4 & 8 No. 5 double desks, a teacher's desk No. 11 & 2 chairs No. 7. These
are taken from Catalogue No. 15 of The Western School Supply Compy., Regina. If The Department would be willing to supply these articles it would meet with my recommendation. It is not likely that the building will be fit for use until the end of September.

I am, Sir,

Your obedient servant

[Signature]
Indian Agent,

The Secretary,

Ottawa

Extract from Inspector's Report on the COLD LAKE School, November 23, 1922.

A garden should be supplied for the teaching of agriculture.

Prispo,
Insp.
Ottawa, April 3rd, 1923.

Sir:

The Public School Inspector, in a report on his inspection of the Cold Lake Indian Day School, suggests that a garden be conducted at the school, for the purpose of teaching the children the management and care of the same.

I have to request that you will ascertain whether the teacher would be prepared to instruct the pupils in the conducting of small garden plots on the school ground, also what would be required to place the ground in suitable condition, and the probable cost of the same. It is considered that a small garden could be conducted with very little expense, and the instruction received would be of benefit to the pupils, and would encourage them to carry on garden plots at their homes. If the teacher will undertake the instruction, you should state the quantity of seeds (vegetable) required, and the cost of putting the ground in condition.

The above matters should receive your prompt attention, in order that, if it is decided to go on with the work, arrangements can be made to begin as soon as weather conditions permit.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

Lane Turner, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Onion Lake, Sask.

Sir:

I have to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 24th ultimo, reporting on your recent visit to the Frog Lake, Long Lake and Cold Lake Indian Day Schools, and informing the Department of the action taken by you in having gardens conducted at each of these schools.

In reply I beg to say that the Department approves of the instructions which you gave to have the necessary ploughing and harrowing done at each of these schools and to have the teachers supplied with vegetable seeds. It is noted that about one quarter acre will be placed in garden at Frog Lake and Long Lake and one half acre at Cold Lake. You should forward properly certified vouchers, in duplicate, for each of these schools, separately, covering the cost of the ploughing, harrowing and seeds.

It is noted that you have authorized fencing at Cold Lake. Accounts should be forwarded covering the expenditure incurred for this purpose, also covering any material supplied the teacher at Frog Lake for painting and whitewashing the interior of the school and for putting the closet in good repair and condition. We hope that the teachers and pupils will meet with success in their gardening operations during the coming summer.

Your obedient servant,

Extract from Inspector's Report on the COLD LAKE DAY SCHOOL, September 11, 1923.

The building used is the property of the Mission. The building would appear to be rather poor for winter use. There is no foundation. The interior is rather dingy. A toilet is needed. The water supply is not good. The general surroundings are good.

C. Crispo, Insp.
Ottawa, October 22nd, 1923.

Sir:

The Public School Inspector, in a report on his inspection of the Cold Lake Indian Day School, has drawn attention to the condition of the mission building which is used for school purposes. This building is rented from the church authorities, and it is considered that they should be responsible for the undertaking of any repairs to make the building comfortable during the coming winter. The Inspector states that there is no foundation under the building, and that the interior is dingy. He also states that a toilet is needed, and that the water supply is not good.

You will be good enough to draw this matter to the attention of Rev. Father Balter, to whom payment of the rent is made, and request him to see that the building is made as comfortable as possible for the coming winter.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

Lang Turner, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Onion Lake, Sask.
Sir,

I have the honour to refer to your letter of the 22nd ultimo, No.115-3-5, and, in reply, to inform you that when at Cold Lake reserve on the 19th instant, I spoke to the Reverend Father Balter with respect to the condition of the building which is used for school purposes; and he told me that he was contemplating the erection, next spring, of a new building for a schoolhouse; and that in the meantime everything possible would be done to make the building at present in use comfortable for the winter.

The school is held in a building formerly used as a residence by the priests at the Mission. It is a two storied log building, 21 feet square, with a single storied leanto 21' by 14'. Mr. Hebert, the school teacher, with his family, used the upper part of the main building and the leanto as a residence; the lower part of the main building was used as the schoolroom. However, on my visit to the school a few days ago, I found that the teacher had moved his family into the schoolroom, and had removed the desks and school equipment into the leanto, and was holding school there. This room is large enough for a schoolroom but is not nearly so comfortable as the one vacated. I told Mr. Hebert that the Department could not approve of the change he had made, but on his promise to cover the leanto with building paper to keep out all drafts, I would ask that the change be countenanced as a temporary measure, to last, certainly, not later than April 1st next. By this time Father Balter's plans for a new building may be completed, and arrangements made between him and Mr. Hebert whereby the latter will be able to use the whole of the present schoolhouse as a residence.

With respect to the need for a toilet. There is one situated about 75 yards from the school and, with Father Balter's permission I will have Mr. Martineau, the Farm Instructor, haul it closer to the schoolhouse.

With respect to the water supply. Several wells have been dug in the vicinity of the Mission and the water, although at first good, has in each case turned alkaline later. A good open creek runs close to the schoolhouse, but there is always the danger of this water containing impurities, and I would recommend that a stone filter be supplied the school. I believe that one holding ten gallons could be purchased for between $25.00 and $30.00.

I trust the Department will approve of the action taken with respect to the schoolroom.

I have the honour to be

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs
Ottawa, Dec. 3rd, 1923.

Sir:

I have to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 26th ultimo, regarding the condition of the mission building which is used for school purposes on the Cold Lake Indian Reserve.

In reply I beg to say it is hoped that this building will be made comfortable and will serve the purpose until next spring, at which time it is noted that the Church authorities contemplate the erection of a new building for a school house.

It is noted that you have arranged to have the farm instructor haul the present toilet to a site nearer to the school.

Regarding the water supply, I beg to say that you may purchase a stone filter to hold approximately 10 gallons, and have it delivered to the school. It will be necessary to obtain competitive prices from a number of dealers, and the purchase should be made from the firm quoting you the lowest price. Properly certified vouchers, in duplicate, should be forwarded covering the cost. It is thought that when this filter is installed it will solve the problem insofar as the supply of drinking water is concerned.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

are held and firmly bound to His Majesty the King, His Heirs, Successors and Assigns in the sum of Sixty-Four 04/100 dollars of lawful money of Canada, for which payment well and truly to be made we bind ourselves and our and each of our heirs, executors and Administrators, firmly by these presents, sealed with our seals and dated this seventh day of January A.D. 1926.

AND WHEREAS the said cheque has since been lost or destroyed having been endorsed by me, the aforesaid payee, before such loss.

AND WHEREAS His Majesty has consented and agreed to issue a new cheque in the place and stead of the one lost as aforesaid, provided we the said Charles T. Hebert and Dorothy W. Shepeshy indemnify and save harmless His Majesty from all loss and damage, and from all costs and charges which may arise from the loss of the said cheque and the issue of a new cheque.

Now, the condition of the above written bond or obligation is such that if the above bounden Charles T. Hebert and Dorothy W. Form No. 1
COLD LAKE DAY SCHOOL

I visited this school on the 7th of September. The teacher, Mr. Chas. Hebert, holds a Second Class Alberta Certificate. The school is held in a building, the property of the Roman Catholic Church. A portion of the building is used as a residence and one of the rooms in size 20 x 22 is a class room. This room is lighted by five small windows which are placed on three sides of the room. I may say that this building is not kept in good condition and in my opinion is not a suitable building for the purpose. When it was taken over I was under the impression that it was only for temporary use. If a day school is to be continued on this reserve I would suggest that a new school and teacher's residence be provided and a site for same selected away from the Church Buildings. At the present site they have to depend on the creek for water which I do not think is safe. An effort has been made to obtain water at this point but it has turned out to be alkali. The Farm Instructor, half a mile away, has excellent water in his well.

There are 20 pupils on the roll at this school, 8 boys and 10 girls. The average attendance for the year is 16. This pupilage is only a proportion of the children of school age belonging to the Cold Lake Band. The Indians have been clamouring for a Boarding School for years. Each trip I make to the reserve that appears to be the question of the greatest importance with them.
Regina, Sask., Sept. 22nd, 1926.

Sir:

I am enclosing herewith a report on the schools in the Onion Lake Agency, which was made by Mr. Inspector Murison.

The Cold Lake school is taught by Chas. Hebert. You will notice that the building here is a poor affair, but I would not advise the Department to spend any money on it, as no doubt the time is coming when a large residential school will be built to take care of the Catholic children of the Saddle Lake and Onion Lake Agencies.

W. M. Graham.
Indian Commissioner.
Onion Lake Agency

Sir,

I have the honour to enclose herewith return of the Cold Lake Indian Day school, for the quarter ended March 31st, past.

With reference to the water supply mentioned by the teacher in the "Remarks" column; a well was bored at the school a few years ago, but the water was very alkali and could not be used. However, water for drinking purposes can be obtained from the Cold Lake farmhouse about half a mile distant from the school.

It might be well to dig a shallow well on the edge of the creek, mentioned by the teacher. This would be very inexpensive, and, I believe, a supply of pure water could be obtained from it.

I have the honour to be,
Sir,
Your obedient servant,
[Signature]
Indian Agent.

Ottawa, April 26th, 1927.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 11th instant, with reference to the water supply for the use of the Cold Lake Indian Day School. In this connection it is noted that the water in the well that was bored a few years' ago is unsuitable for use.

If you consider that it would be satisfactory to dig a shallow well on the edge of the creek, which could be done at little expense, and the water would be suitable for drinking purposes, you may arrange to have this work done. Please keep the expense down to the lowest possible point, and when the work has been completed to your satisfaction, you should forward properly certified vouchers, in duplicate, covering the expenditure incurred. You should give this matter your early attention.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Acting Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

dated Oct. 27, 1927, on his inspection
of the Cold Lake Indian Day School.

Original on File 115-3-6.

The pupils are taught knitting by Mrs. Hebert and can do very good work. Additional towels should be supplied and the pupils given more hygiene drill.
Ottawa, November 15, 1927.

Sir:

The Public School Inspector, in a report on his recent inspection of the Cold Lake Indian Day School, recommends that additional towels be supplied, and that the pupils be given more hygiene drill. You may arrange for the purchase and delivery of 6 yards of towelling, and you should inform the teacher of the inspector's recommendation regarding the teaching of hygiene to the pupils. Should any tooth brushes be needed, the same will be forwarded upon receipt of a requisition for the number required.

After you have purchased the towelling, please forward an account, in duplicate, properly certified, in the usual manner covering the cost.

Your obedient servant,

CANADA

COMMISSIONER'S OFFICE.

W. REGINA, SASK., April 4th, 1928.

INSPECTION REPORT ON SCHOOLS ONION LAKE AGENCY.

Dear Mr. Graham:

I beg to submit the following report on the three Day Schools and the two Residential Schools, which are situated on reserves included in the Onion Lake Agency.

COLD LAKE DAY SCHOOL.

I visited this Day School on the 5th of March and found 24 pupils present, 12 boys and 12 girls, out of an enrollment of 36. The average attendance for the previous month was about 20. The average attendance for the December quarter, 1927, was 12.86 and for the June quarter, 1927, was 11.59. The increased attendance is attributed to the fact that a hot bowl of soup has been given to the children at mid-day, in addition to the regular issue of biscuits. The Priest, in charge of the Mission, purchased beef, beans, lard and tea at a cost of $5.70 and this provided a bowl of soup for each child for three weeks at a cost of less than one cent per meal. The attendance has nearly doubled since they commenced giving the soup. The teacher was very anxious to provide the soup during the cold weather, and, as I was impressed with the good results which had already been obtained, I purchased $5.00 worth of meat at my own expense to enable them to carry on during the month of March.

The Indians of the Cold Lake Band have bee

W. M. Graham, Esq.,
Indian Commissioner,
Regina, Sask.
have been hunters and still follow that vocation. It takes them away from their reserve a great deal, and, as they in many instances take their families with them, the regular attendance at the school is naturally affected to a considerable extent by this. It is a fact, that here, as well as on other reserves where we have Day schools, many of the children go to school in the morning with practically empty stomachs and are listless. In consequence, it is noted that after getting their bowl of wholesome soup they are much brighter in the afternoon. I do not think it necessary to provide an expensive meal, and realize that at some schools where the privilege has been granted there has been the tendency to abuse it, but I firmly believe that the provision of a bowl of nourishing soup has a very beneficial effect on the health and comfort of the children attending our Day Schools.

This school is held in a building, which was formerly the Priests' Residence and which is rented for school purposes from them. I do not consider it a suitable for the purpose, but rather as a make-shift, pending the provision of a more suitable building. I found the building clean and the children appeared warmly clad. It was noted that they have a water cooler, only one wash basin and no tooth brushes. I have spoken to the Agent regarding providing them with towelling, which he has in stock at the Agency store house, to enable them to have individual towels.

Mr. Charles Hebert, the teacher, holds a Second Class Alberta certificate. He appears very painstaking and interested in his work. I consider that he is doing as well as can be expected under the circumstances. It is very discouraging for a teacher where the attendance is so intermittent. The school room was clean and tidy. The pupils are taught knitting by Mrs. Hebert. A garden has been put in during the past three years, but has not proved a success, as the ground in the vicinity of the school appears unsuitable.
Dear Mr. Scott:

I am enclosing herewith Inspector Murison's report on the various schools in the Onion Lake Agency. The report is very complete and the Inspector has gone into matters very thoroughly.

With reference to the Cold Lake Day School, I notice that the Priest in charge of the Mission purchased beef, beans, lard and tea at a cost of $5.70 and provided a bowl of soup for each child at a cost of less than one cent per meal. I do not think the Department want to call on the Priest to provide this food for the Indian school children and I am of the opinion that they would be willing to make a small grant for this purpose, say five or six dollars a month. I should be glad if action on these lines could be taken, as I do not think it is the intention of the Department that children should go to Day school on empty stomachs as is pointed out by the Inspector.

W. M. Graham.
Indian Commissioner.
Ottawa, April 20th, 1928.

Sir:

With reference to that portion of your No. 309-11 of the 10th instant, enclosing Inspector Morrison's report on his inspection of the Cold Lake Indian Day School, I beg to say, with reference to the supplies required for the midday meal, that the Department would be prepared to allow an amount of approximately $5 per month during the winter months, in order to purchase the beef, beans, tea, etc., required in giving the pupils a hot lunch at midday, and I shall be pleased if you will arrange with the local Indian Agent to furnish the supplies, the cost of which should not exceed approximately the amount mentioned each month. Accounts should be forwarded from time to time covering the expenditure.

It is noted that the teacher is interested in his work and that he is doing as well as can be expected.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Acting Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

W. M. Graham, Esq.,
Indian Commissioner,
Regina, Sask.
Le Goff, Alberta,
April 24, 1928.

I am compelled to address myself to you on the following questions.

I have been teaching here for five years. Have asked for more fuel to heat the school. I receive only $30. a year. The last five years have cost me an average of $70. not including $30. allowance. This I had to pay from my own pocket. I understand that many day schools receive as far as $170. for fuel. Is there any reason why I should be limited to a little $30. a year.

Nothing is furnished on the line of midday meal except biscuits. When bacon, rice, rolled oats etc. could be given, attendance was very much better. Is there no way of giving those poor little Indian children a better meal at noon?

Chas. P. Hebert,
Teacher, Le Goff, Alberta.
Ottawa, May 5, 1928.

Dear Mr. Hebert,

The Honourable the Superintendent General has directed me to reply to your letter of the 24th ultimo which has reference to your activity at the Cold Lake Indian Day School. In connection with the fuel allowance, I wish to point out that the Department made an agreement with the local missionary to the effect that the rental of $20 per teaching month should include the necessary heating and caretaking. Accordingly, your request for an increased fuel allowance should be made to Rev. Father Lacombe. With reference to the midday lunch, I have to inform you that on the 20th ultimo, following receipt of Mr. Inspector Hurison's report, the Department authorized an expenditure of $5 per month during the winter months so that some beef, beans, tea, etc., could be provided.

When you were appointed in 1922, you were allowed salary at the rate of $300 for the ten teaching months, and, in addition, Mrs. Hebert was allowed $500 per annum for her services as field matron. It is true that you have given satisfaction, and in 1924 an increase of $100 was allowed in your case.

In your letter to Mr. Stewart, you leave the impression that your salary has never been increased since your appointment and that at present it is only $350 for the ten teaching months. May I point out that you are in receipt of $300, and when the salary of Mrs. Hebert is added thereto, it makes a total of $400, which I feel compares quite favourable with remuneration paid to workers in rural day schools in the province.

I am pleased to inform you that, in harmony with the Department's practice to recognize satisfactory services, I have directed that an increase of $50 be granted in your case as from the 1st of September, next.

Yours very truly,

Duncan C. Scott

Deputy Superintendent General.

Chas. P. Hebert, Esq.,
Teacher, Cold Lake Indian Day School,
Legoff, Alta.

Onion Lake,
Sask.
Sir,

I have the honour to refer to your letter of April 26th, 1927, No. 115-3-5, in which authority was given to dig a shallow well on the edge of a creek at Cold Lake reserve, to supply the Cold Lake Indian Day School with water. This reserve is about 75 miles from the Agency, so, as I could not give personal supervision to the digging of the well I placed the matter in the hands of the school teacher to hire men and have the well made. However, for one reason and another he was unable to do this last fall, and on my visit to the school yesterday the Rev. Father Lacombe, who is in charge of the Roman Catholic Mission at Cold Lake, suggested to me that he would have a well bored for the joint use of the mission and Day School, and that the Department would bear half of the cost, to which proposal I gave my consent, subject to the approval of the Department. I estimate that the total cost of the well will not exceed $100.00; the Department's share should, therefore, not exceed $50.00. Water for this Indian Day School is a vital necessity; I trust, therefore, that my action will be approved by the Department.

I have the honour to be,
Sir,
Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent.

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
Ottawa, June 1st, 1928.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 24th ultimo, relative to the boring of a well for the use of the Cold Lake Indian Day School.

In this connection it is noted that arrangements can be made with the missionary at Cold Lake to have a well bored for the joint use of the mission and day school, and that the estimated cost will not exceed $100, each party to be responsible for half the cost. The Department will approve of the arrangement which you have made with the missionary for the boring of the well, and will, upon receipt of a voucher, in duplicate, certified by you, pay half the cost of boring this well.

Your obedient servant,

T. R. L. MacInnes,
Acting Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

Lang Turner, Esq.,
Indian Agent,

DEPARTMENT OF INDIAN AFFAIRS
CANADA

COMMISSIONER'S OFFICE,

NOV 24 1928
REGINA, SASK., November 23rd, 1928.

INSPECTION REPORT ON SCHOOLS, ONION LAKE AGENCY.

Dear Mr. Graham:

I beg to submit the following report on the three day schools and the two residential schools which are situated on reserves included in the Onion Lake Agency.

COLD LAKE INDIAN DAY SCHOOL.

I visited this day school on the 18th of October. There are 15 Indian pupils enrolled for this month, 7 boys and 8 girls. There are, in addition, 3 girls belonging to the farming instructor, 2 boys belonging to the teacher and 1 halfbreed girl in attendance. The enrolment at this school has been reduced owing to a large number of children having been transferred to the Onion Lake R.C. Residential School. The attendance, in proportion to the enrolment, has shown an improvement this year.

Since my last visit provision has been made for a supply of skim milk for this school during the summer months and bowl of soup for the winter. The furnishing of a warm meal would commence on November 1st. The furnishing of these additions to the biscuits for the mid day lunch has been greatly appreciated, and the teacher informs me it has had a beneficial effect on the attendance.

I have already reported on the school building at this point. It is not a suitable building.

W. M. Graham, Esq.,
Indian Commissioner,
Regina, Sask.
GOLD LAKE INDIAN DAY SCHOOL (CONT'D.)

As I have already stated, for school purposes and I think was only intended for a makeshift when the school was re-opened.

I found both the schoolroom and the children clean and tidy.

There are no facilities for recreation at this school and I would recommend that teeters and swings be provided as has been done at Long Lake and Frog Lake. These do not cost much and are splendid recreation for the children.

Mr. Charles Hebert remains in charge as teacher at this point and his wife, Mrs. Hebert, takes an interest in teaching knitting to the children, as well as preparing the lunch at mid day.

FROG LAKE INDIAN DAY SCHOOL.

I visited the Frog Lake Day School on the afternoon of the 18th of October. There are 17 enrolled at this school, 10 boys and 7 girls; of these, 7 boys and 6 girls were present. The attendance at this school has been better since my last visit, but there is still a great deal of room for improvement.

Since my last visit the teacher has been supplied with Drinilk during the summer months. He states that the children are not very partial to it, but they like it when boiled with rice and they have been giving it to them in this manner. This will be substituted on November 1st and during the winter months with a warm bowl of soup and tea. There is no doubt that the providing of this inexpensive meal is a great boon to the children.

The children
FROG LAKE INDIAN DAY SCHOOL (CONT'D.)

The children are required to clean themselves up when they come to the school and they had adequate clothing for the season.

I reported on the condition of the school building last year. The conditions are practically the same only the school does not present so good an appearance as in the winter time as the rains had washed the mud off in streaks. Both the teacher's residence and the school are log buildings and are plastered with mud. It is hard to keep the buildings in repair and I would suggest that these buildings be plastered with lime and sand. I would also suggest that a small addition to the house be allowed for a summer kitchen and storage. The total cost of these repairs should not exceed $150.00.

The teacher has a small garden which was fairly good this year.

Mr. A. B. Peterson is still holding the position of teacher. He appears to be a man of good common sense and has practical experience, apart from his teaching ability, in western farming. His presence on the reserve has a good influence, but his authority over the Indians is, of course, very limited.

KEDHEWING INDIAN DAY SCHOOL. (Longfellow)

I visited this school on October 31st and found 4 boys and 2 girls present out of an enrolment of 10. The teacher's 3 girls were also present. They are attending the school, but are not shown on the register.

Mr. Francis Dion, the teacher, continues to be quite faithful to his duties, and I considered his work quite commendable, considering the disadvantages that he
that he has to work with, particularly insofar as the irregularity of the attendance is concerned.

The children were quite clean and tidy and healthy looking.

The school building was also clean and presented a good appearance. Since my last visit this building has been plastered with lime and sand and whitewashed. Only the school was re-plastered with lime and sand. When I suggested the re-plastering of these buildings in my last report, I included the teacher's residence, but the Agent apparently was under the impression that only the school building was to be done. I think that the teacher's residence should be re-plastered with lime and sand. It is a difficult matter, where they live in houses the year around, to keep them looking decent. These buildings would look better if the roof and the gable ends were painted. The outside closets should also be painted. The teacher has asked for doorsteps in front of the school. These might be supplied, and also 1 large and 1 small iron gate for the fence. A new well is also required at this school. The present well does not furnish an adequate supply for the use of the school and teacher's residence.

The teacher also asks if he might be provided with pictures of the King and Queen and some other prominent men as well. We have pictures of the King and Queen in practically all of our schools and I would recommend that the Department supply these.
ONION LAKE CHURCH OF ENGLAND RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL.

I visited this school on October 24th, and made a careful inspection of the school and outbuildings. I found the school buildings in a well kept condition.

There are 80 pupils enrolled at this school; 77 were present on the day of my visit, 44 boys and 33 girls. The pupils were clean and tidy and had a healthy appearance. I am informed that there has been very little illness at this school during the past year.

I was present at the children's noon-day meal and noted that they had an ample supply of wholesome food. The children receive all the milk that they care to drink. They were milking 8 cows at the time of my visit, which gives them an ample supply for the children.

The Rev. H. Ellis, Principal, has as a staff 7 women, 1 of whom is a trained nurse and 2 are properly qualified teachers. The kitchen matron was absent on the day of my visit on account of sickness. Mr. D. Spooner, the Farming Instructor, appears to be a competent man. Mr. W. Gravil, the Engineer, impresses me as being a first class man for the position. He appears to thoroughly understand the operation of the plant and is quite capable of doing the necessary repair work. I found everything in the boiler and engine room in first class condition.

Mr. Gravil brought to my attention that the water system was not available for fire protection in the engine and boiler rooms and stated that if he was supplied with a 1½" hose connection and 50 ft. of fire hose, he could do the work himself and provide protection for that wing of the building. They have one large size extinguisher in the boiler room. He also pointed out that a ventilating fan installed in the chimney.
chimney would carry off the battery and gas fumes from the engine room. He tells me that at times these are quite strong.

I examined the fire fighting equipment and found it to be in good working order. The plant appears to be operating satisfactorily. They are still using the farm engine to pump water from the lake.

OUTBUILDINGS.

Since my last visit, the stanchions in the cow barn have been raised and re-set in cement. The hay carrier track has also been repaired. I noted an improvement in the condition of the outbuildings and in the tidiness of the premises. A separate sewage disposal system has been installed in connection with the Principal's residence and is very much appreciated. It is working very satisfactorily.

FARM.

The school crop this year consisted of 50 acres of wheat, 75 acres of oats and 13 acres of barley. The sample of the grain has been considerably spoiled as a result of frost. Only 1019 bushels of wheat were threshed; this will possibly grade 5 or 6 Northern. 656 bushels of oats were threshed from 25 acres and 50 acres of oats were not considered worth threshing and were kept for feed. 13 acres of barley yielded 199 bushels. It is too bad that this grain was frozen as they had the promise of an excellent crop of wheat. The frost also effected the yield of their garden produce.

The stock now consist of 29 cattle, 12 of which are milch cows. They have 4 good work horses, 2 old horses and 2 drivers. They require another team. They have 25 poultry and 17 hogs.
ONION LAKE C. OF R. RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL (CONT'D.)

I may say that I was better pleased with conditions at this school than I have been on any previous visit.

ONION LAKE R.C. RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL.

I visited this school on three occasions during my stay at Onion Lake. All the details in connection with the construction of this school had not been completed. The electric lighting plant was installed at the time of my visit and the water system was also completed. It appears that there has been a great deal of difficulty experienced in getting the contractors to complete their work. I examined the plumbing system and the heating and lighting plant, and the work in connection with these appears to have been well done. There appears to have been no provision made for a chimney for the laundry and bake oven. They require a stove in the laundry for the purpose of heating irons. The laundry floor has not sufficient fall to carry off the surplus water. As a matter of fact, the fall appears to be away from the drain instead of to it. This is a detail that was pointed out by the Sisters and is not being mentioned here with a view to fault finding.

The fire fighting equipment consists of 2 sets of hose on each floor attached to the water supply system. This equipment, being new, is in first class condition. I noted that there were no fire extinguishers and would point out that at all our residential schools, in addition to the hose, we have 2 fire extinguishers on each floor. Access to the fire escapes is obtained through rooms occupied by members of the staff.

The school has been very nicely equipped with new furniture. The Rev.
ONION LAKE R.C. RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL (CONT'D.)

The Rev. Father Balter, O.M.I., is in charge as Principal. Mr. Balduc is the Farming Instructor and Mr. Rose is Engineer. There are 6 Sisters of Charity, 3 of whom are teachers. The Sister Superior is the business manager of the institution and appears to exercise supervision over the outside operations as the present Principal is not a practical man being more of a student.

FARM:

This year they had their first crop. 30 acres of wheat produced 573 bushels; 45 acres of oats yielded 2300 bushels. Their garden produced 400 bushels of potatoes, not sufficient for their requirements. The wheat was a good quality of Garnet and will make excellent seed. They will realize a good price for this.

Their stock consists of 13 cattle, including 8 milking cows, 7 horses, 16 pigs and 75 hens. Mr. Balduc appears to be a good farmer and a careful man with stock.

I was very unfavourably impressed with Rose, the Engineer. He had a great deal of fault to find with the plant which he is expected to operate and has succeeded in getting the Principal and the Sister Superior very much dissatisfied. He found fault with the plumbing, the boilers, the electric lighting plant and the water supply system. Even the engine wasn't properly constructed. Everything was wrong. I was presented by the Principal with a typewritten list of all the imperfections in connection with this plant and came to the conclusion, after examining the plant, that Mr. Rose was making a big noise to hide his own incompetence. This man is a trouble maker pure and simple, in my opinion, and I think the wrong class of man to have associated in any way with an institution of this kind.

The outside
The outside dwelling for the Farming Instructor, as well as the poultry house and implement shed, were nearing completion at the time of my visit.

There are 92 pupils enrolled, 50 boys and 42 girls. The children looked well nourished. There were a few cases of whooping cough and 3 children were sent to the hospital while I was there being typhoid suspects.

This being the first summer that this school has been occupied and as work has been under construction during the whole period, very little has been done towards beautifying the grounds, but as soon as the construction work and buildings are completed, the premises can be put in shape.

The foregoing report is respectfully submitted.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

W. Morrison,
Inspector of Indian Agencies.
DEPARTMENT OF INDIAN AFFAIRS
CANADA

COMMISSIONER'S OFFICE.

REGINA, SASK., Nov. 29th, 1928.

Dear Mr. Scott:

I am enclosing herewith a report on the schools in the Onion Lake Agency, which were visited by Mr. Inspector Murison.

Swings and teeters for the Cold Lake Indian Day School have been asked for in the Estimates. I have been trying to supply Drimilk wherever they will make good use of it. I note it is being used at this school.

The teacher's residence at Frog Lake might be improved but it seems to me that nothing much can be done to make it more habitable.

With reference to the Inspector's remarks regarding the teacher's residence at the Keeheewin Day School, probably the reason that the building was not re-plastered was because it was the intention of the Agent to line it with siding. This has been asked for in the Estimates that were forwarded, also an amount for painting the interior. I think if this were done it would make a better building.

You will note what Mr. Gravil, the Engineer at the Onion Lake C. of E. School asks for in the way of hose for fire protection. This might be authorized.

Duncan C. Scott, Esq.,
Deputy Supt. General,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
You will also note what the Inspector says regarding the completion of the contract at the new R.C. Indian Residential School. He states that no provision was made for chimneys in the laundry and bake-oven. This may or may not have been an oversight, as they may have had some other scheme in view when the plans were drawn. He also complains about the manner in which the laundry floor has been built. I do not know whether this was in accordance with the details of the plans or not. Mr. Hamilton has gone to this school to make a final report and the Department will then be in a position to know just how the matter stands. One matter, however, I think should not escape the attention of the Department, and that is that the Inspector says he was not impressed with the Engineer. I do not know whether this man has the proper qualifications or not, but if he has not he should have been replaced. It is absolutely wrong to have an incompetent man handling a plant of this kind, as he can do more damage in a few months than we should expect to occur in ten years. I would ask the Department to look carefully into this man's qualifications. The Inspector remarks that he has a great deal to say. I found this to be the case when I was at this school.

Yours very truly,

W. M. Graham,
Indian Commissioner.
Ottawa, December 6, 1928.

Sir:

I have been directed to acknowledge receipt of your No. 309-11 of the 29th ultimo, enclosing the report of Mr. Inspector Murison on his inspection of the various schools in the Onion Lake Agency. The various matters referred to by the Inspector as requiring attention at the schools will receive consideration. We are pleased to note that the conditions generally at these schools are fairly satisfactory. Certain of the matters referred to by the Inspector will form the subject of separate communications to you.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

W. M. Graham, Esq.,
Indian Commissioner,
Regina, Sask.
Ottawa, December 6, 1928.

Sir:

Mr. Inspector Murison, in a report on his recent inspection of the Cold Lake Indian Day School, recommends that teetors and swings be provided as playground equipment for the use of the pupils, the same as has been done at the Long Lake and Frog Lake Day Schools. It is, no doubt, too late this season to have this equipment installed, but you should draw the matter to the attention of the Department early next spring, giving full particulars as to the equipment you would recommend be supplied and the cost of same. I may say that the Inspector found conditions at this school to be satisfactory.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

Lang Turner, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Onion Lake, Sask.

I have the honour to refer to your letter of December 6th last, No.115-3-5 and to draw the attention of the Department to the matter of supplying play-ground equipment in the form of teeters and swings for the use of the pupils at the Cold Lake Day School.

I estimate that the approximate cost of the equipment will be as follows:

- Teeters: $18.00
- Double swing: $25.00
- Seesaw: $15.00

Labour; setting the above in cement and painting same: $17.00

Total: $75.00

This amount was included in my estimates for 1929 - 1930.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent.

The Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
Ottawa, March 25, 1929.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 15th instant, giving an estimate of the cost of playground equipment for the use of the pupils at the Cold Lake Indian Day School.

In reply I beg to say that you may arrange, as soon as weather conditions permit, to have a tester, double swing and see saw erected on the school grounds. The total cost for the material and labour should not exceed your estimate of $75.

After this playground equipment has been completed, you should forward an account, in duplicate, properly certified, covering the expenditure incurred.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Acting Aest., Deputy and Secretary.

Lang Turner, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Onion Lake, Sask.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 13th instant, requesting that a football be supplied for each of the Frog Lake, Long Lake, Cold Lake and Ministikwan Indian Day Schools.

In reply I have to say that the Department is placing an order here for the supplying of these footballs. When same are received, they will be forwarded to you to be handed to the teacher of each of the above named schools.

Dear Sir,

During my recent visit to your office I regret to say that I forgot to mention the appointment of Rev. Father Jos. Portier to the post of Principal of the Union Lake Indian Residential School. I hope you will have no objection to approve of the same.

I enclose herewith a cheque to the amount of $60.00 made in favour of Rev. Father E. Lacombe for the rent of a building at Cold Lake. As Father Lacombe has been removed to Delmas, Sask., and replaced by Father L. Balter the Bank refused to pay the cheque on account of not bearing the proper endorsement. Would you be kind enough to have another cheque issued in favour of the actual Principal.

Dear Mr Scott, I thank you very much for the cordial reception with which you and all the other officers of your Department have recently favored me.

Yours very truly,

H. Langlois

The right honorable
Blood Reserve Sept 2, 1899.

I have the honour to make a few remarks regarding
the difficulties in recruiting pupils for the Boarding
Schools.

There is on the Reserve several Indians having
half breed children living with them, drawing
rations and money treaty. There is also
in a very miserable situation viz., a certain
Indian woman has been living with a white
man for 6 or 7 years but never lawfully married
with him. The white man is now dead and the
Indian woman is now living on the Reserve with 3 children.
The poor squaw has lost her ration for herself and the
3 children. She would like to have them in a Boarding School,
but the pupils not being in the treaty would receive no grant
of education from the Indian Department. The case of these
children is then worse than if they were pure Indians.

I take the liberty to draw your attention on these
poor children, and I would suggest a grant of
education to be authorized to them, that they may
be admitted in a Boarding School. As for their
supporting on the Reserve I would suggest a certain rule
equal for every one of these children half breed.

With regard to the age for admitting pupils in the Boarding
School, I am aware of the rule of the Department, but when the
Indians are willing to give up their children at 5 years old will the Depart-
ment give them the grant of education. I hope, considering the difficulties in recrui-
ting pupils, the Department will have no objection for their admission,
and in the past the same has been done for other schools.

Having a satisfactory answer, I have the honour to be
Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Your obedient servant,

J. B. McLean

Sir,

I have the honor to enclose herewith a copy of a letter from the Principal of the Roman Catholic Boarding School on the Blood Reserve and would be glad to have a report from you on the subject of the admission into boarding schools of the class of pupils referred to.

I have the honor to be, sir,

Your obedient servant,

Office of the Indian Commissioner

for Manitoba and the North West Territories.

In your reply refer to No. 129/73 and date of this letter and address Mr. David Laird, Indian Commissioner, Winnipeg, Man.

Winnipeg, 19 Sept. 1899.

Sir,

I have the honour to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 14th instant, and enclosure, being a letter to the Department from Rev. Father Riou, O.M.I., of the Blood Reserve, and to say that I have thoroughly considered the matter of admitting non-treaty children into our schools and have come to the conclusion that it should not take place. There are thousands of these outcasts in the country and the admission of some, even of the most needful, means that of all, which the Department has refused to countenance, on principle. Several exceptions have been made in the past which have led to worrying correspondence and strife between clergymen of different denominations.

I have therefore made an absolute rule, of which all parties concerned have been duly notified, and must say that, but for the pity of having children ill-cared for in our midst, the rule is working satisfactorily. I may also add that the local Government of the N.W.Territories has not closed its eyes to the educational wants of these people and is quite willing to provide teachers salaries to competent persons teaching in our schools, qualified according to the N.W.T.School Ordinance, and subject to the government's inspection.

The Secretary

Dept. of Indian Affairs,

Ottawa.
inspection. Two schools have already been granted this privilege which can be had for the mere matter of the asking. This enables the school authorities to have competent teachers at no cost practically, whilst otherwise they in many cases have to pay salaries to incompetent ones.

It of course stands to reason that this can be carried out only where there is room for admission of half-breeds and providing that no detriment is experienced as regards Indians.

From a late report from Mr. Inspector Chisholm, recently forwarded to the department, it will be seen that the halfbreed inmates in the Church of England Onion Lake Boarding School, are much more numerous than the Indians; here the local government upon request immediately agreed to pay the salary of one duly qualified teacher.

In regard to the age of admission of Indian children into Boarding Schools I think that these should not be considered as nurseries and that six years is as low an age as should entitle a child to the privilege.

Your obedient servant,

Indian Commissioner.
Ottawa, 18th October, 1899.

Memorandum Mr. Smart,

The Indian Commissioner is to be informed, in reply to his letter of the 19th ultimo, that I have given the subject referred to therein careful consideration, and that I cannot approve of the absolute rule which he has laid down that none but treaty children are to be admitted into Indian schools. A well defined line can be drawn between Halfbreeds, properly speaking, and Indians. While I do not consider that the children of the Halfbreeds proper of Manitoba and the Territories should be admitted into Indian schools and paid for by the Department, I am decidedly of the opinion that all children of mixed blood, whether legitimate or not, who live upon an Indian Reserve and whose parents live as Indians upon a Reserve, even if they are not ammitants, should be eligible for admission to the schools. It must be remembered that
that boarding and Industrial schools were not established for the purpose of carrying out the terms of the treaty or complying with any provision of the law, but were instituted in the public interest, so that there should not grow up upon reserves an uneducated and barbarous class. The North West Government cannot provide for the education of non-annuitants upon reserves; and if we exclude them from our schools, they will practically be debarred from all means of education.
Ottawa, 24th October, 1890.

Sir,

The Minister has had under careful consideration your letter of the 10th ultimo, Ref.180145, addressed to the Secretary of the Department, and he has come to the conclusion that he cannot approve of the absolute rule which you have laid down that none but treaty children are to be admitted into Indian schools. A well defined line can be drawn between Half-breeds, properly speaking, and Indians, and while the Minister does not consider that the children of the Half-breeds proper, of Manitoba and the Territories, should be admitted into Indian Schools and paid for by the Department, still he is decidedly of the opinion that all children, even those of mixed blood, whether legitimate or not, who live upon an Indian Reserve and whose parents on either side live as Indians upon a Reserve, even if they are not annuitants, should be eligible for admission to the schools. It should be remembered in this connection that boarding and industrial schools were not established for the purpose of carrying out the terms of the treaty, or complying with any provision of the law, but that they were instituted in the public interest, so that there should not grow up upon reserves an uneducated and barbarous class. The North West Government cannot provide for the education of non-annuitants upon reserves, and if we should exclude them from our schools, they would practically be debarred from all means of education.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,

[Signature]

Indian Commissioner,
Winnipeg, Man.

Deputy Superintendent General
I have the honour to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 24th ultimo, and to say that the Minister's conclusion will be accorded its proper weight.

I would, however, remark that I did not consider that on the question referred to I was making any new rule - on the contrary the object I was endeavoring to accomplish was to carry out what I regarded to be the meaning of the 138th Section of the Indian Act and the Orders in Council based thereon. The Industrial and Boarding Schools are there mentioned as "for Indians". Sub-section 2 of said section 138 does refer to "children of Indian blood"; but regulation 9 of the Order in Council of Nov. 10, 1894 restricts its application to "any Indian child". The children of White men are not Indians, and I thought that ruling as I did in the case brought before the Minister by Rev. Father Riou, O.M.I., I was carrying out the law.

Yours truly,

Indian Commissioner.

Jas. A. Smart Esq.
Deputy of the Superintendent General of Indian Affairs.
Ottawa.

Principal of the Roman Catholic Boarding School
Blood Reserve,

Honourable Sir,

I beg to say that the number of the pupils of the Roman Catholic Boarding School, Blood Reserve amounts now to 28 children and I have sent you lately through the Indian Agent Mr. Wilson four applications for children's admission.

I am glad to say that the Indians begin to understand the value of education and they are stirring up now to send their children to the school.

The R.C. Boarding School is in the fifth year of its existence; for a long time very few children were admitted and the Honourable Mr. Laird and the Indian Agent Mr. Wilson were at a time discouraged to see so few children in such a large house as our school, and the same gentlemen were coaxing the missionaries here to recruit more children.

The Indian Department has been kind enough to give a grant for twenty-five children from the beginning in November 1898; but today, with 28 children, there are three over the number allowed, and more are coming, and I may say through the great help of the head-chief Cropped ear wolf; this shows the change in the ideas of the Indians about education. So, I feel confident that till the end of this fiscal year you will kindly allow us to admit all the children presented and give the grant for them, and for next year you will allow us the grant for forty (40) children and I feel sure that before the end of next year we will reach that number.

It would be hard for us to support many children over the number granted, and it cannot be thought of
refusing the children presented; this would ruin our future recruiting.

Hoping to receive a satisfactory answer, I remain

Honourable Sir,

your devoted servant,

J.J. Le Vern, ome principal.

Ottawa, April 5, 1907.

The Deputy Superintendent General,

With reference to the transfer of a Catholic child to a Protestant school, referred to in Bishop of St. Albert's letter to the Minister I beg to say that the returns are in up to December 31, last, and show no record of any such transfer having been made.

If Mr. Agent Wilson acted as stated, he was going contrary to the regulations relating to the education of Indian children, which provide that no Protestant child shall be placed in a Roman Catholic school or in a school conducted under the auspices of the Roman Catholics and no Roman Catholic child shall be placed in a Protestant school or in a school conducted under Protestant auspices. (See Sec. 14)

It is, however, competent for parents to change their religion and in such case, upon evidence of the fact being brought before the Department, an order would be made for the discharge of the children from the school in which they were originally placed; or, if parents while remaining Roman Catholics are desirous that their children should be taken into and educated in a Protestant school, upon a written statement to that effect, signed by the parents, there is no objection to their admission. The consent above referred to must be given in the presence of the Agent and certified by him as being understood by the parents and embodying their wishes. This ruling was made by the late Minister on May 27, 1899, and is still
The Agent has no authority to act on his own initiative in this connection. Any discharge or transfer for the reasons above stated would have to be submitted to the Department for its approval before being operative.

[Signature]

Agent might be asked if such has been done.

Sir,

It has been reported to the Department that Mr. Agent Wilson authorized the transfer of a pupil from the Roman Catholic to the Protestant Boarding School on the Blood reserve. The records of the Department do not show that any such transfer has taken place, but, if Mr. Wilson, as stated, authorized the same, he has exceeded his authority, as the regulations relating to the education of Indian children provide that no Protestant child shall be placed in a Roman Catholic school or in a school conducted under the auspices of the Roman Catholics and no Roman Catholic child shall be placed in a Protestant school or in a school conducted under Protestant auspices. (See Sec. 14).

It is, however, competent for parents to change their religion and in such case, upon evidence of the fact being brought before the Department, an order would be made for the discharge of the children from the school in which they were originally placed; or, if parents while remaining Roman Catholics are desirous that their children should be taken into and educated in a Protestant school, upon a written statement to that effect, signed by the parents, there is no objection to their admission.

Sir,

I am in receipt of your letter of the 9th instant stating that it has been reported to the Department that Mr. Agent Wilson authorized the transfer of a pupil from the Roman Catholic to the Protestant Boarding School on the Blood Reserve. Mr. Agent Wilson is not to blame in the matter as he acted under my instructions.

This is one of those troublesome cases, where friction has arisen between two schools of different creeds, and I have to decide as impartially as my judgment enables me.

The child, a boy of the name of Joseph Wells, or Heavy Head, was never admitted by me as a pupil of the R. C. School on the Blood reserve, consequently a transfer in the proper sense of the word was not made. He was only taken from that school where he had been staying a few weeks to the St. Paul's School to which his admission had been formally granted.

The father of the boy, James Wells, deserted the boy's mother and the child when he was a baby and took no further interest in them. He was then taken in charge of by his grandfather, Heavy Head. On September 18, 1905, Heavy Head signed an application for the boy's admission to the St. Paul's School, but the application was not then forwarded to me as the child was too young. Being offended at the Principal of the St. Paul's School over some

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
some matter, Heavy Head on January 5, 1907, signed another application to have the boy admitted to the R. C. Boarding School. I received this application on the 18th February, but did not immediately act upon it, having been informed of the prior application. On the 23rd February I wrote to Mr. Agent Wilson a letter relating to this boy and another, copy of which is placed herewith. On the 6th March I received a reply from the Agent, a copy of which is also enclosed. On the 19th March, having this new application in hand, I admitted the boy to St. Paul's School, as per copy of letter enclosed. If I have done wrong the Department can easily overrule my decision.

Yours truly,

Indian Commissioner.
