Honourable Sir,

I received the official cheque of the Department, $76 No. 2067.

I would beg to state that, to my estimation, this amount is far from being the correct one, as I expect to get the grant per capita for fifty pupils.

Last year, on April 30th '07, I received from the Honourable Mr. Laird, Winnipeg, a letter No. 122/73, stating that the grant per capita for the maintenance of the pupils was found in the estimates, viz; 50 boarders at $72 and that the increased provision was available from the first of April. In fact, the grant for all the pupils entered in the books was duly received ever since. I was somewhat surprised last week when I received the official cheque No. 2067.

I looked over again to the quarterly returns, and I am convinced that this amount $76 is not correct. I hope that you can see to this and that you are as kind as to forward to us the grant as you did before, that is, according to the letter No. 122/73, dated Winnipeg April 30th '07.
As to the balance, you are in a better position than myself to know how much would amount this balance, but I trust that you settle up the matter in a satisfactory way.

Sir,

I am in receipt of a letter from the Principal of the R. C. Boarding School on the Blood Reserve complaining about the payment of the grant for the June quarter last. The Department cannot be called to account as the grant was apparently paid on the basis of 40 boarders which is the number provided. However, the Principal was wrongly informed as early as April 1907 that the grant was provided for 50. I cannot account for this grave error, except that the information was gathered from an unrevised copy of the estimates; for in my estimate as submitted to the Department for both this and last fiscal year I asked provision for 50 boarders.

The matter is further complicated by the fact that the Department before the last quarter actually paid for more than 40 pupils, which encouraged the Principal in gathering more children than were provided for.

Under the circumstances I feel justified in recommending that the Principal be paid for all the pupils he has under 50 for both the June quarter and the following quarter just ended. I would also press that the authorized attendance be increased to fifty. I am anxious to have a favorable answer at an early day.

Your obedient servant,

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Dear Sir:

Rev. Father Salmon, principal of the Roman Catholic school on the Blood reserve, represents that for the year 1907 the school was allowed to draw aid on a pupilage up to fifty. For the past year it was only allowed to draw aid on a pupilage of forty, while he asserts that he had forty-eight pupils in attendance.

There seems to be no good reasons why the decrease should be made, and if there is some reason which I do not know of, I suggest that the step be taken to place the school in the position in which it was in 1907 as to pupilage, and notify the principal accordingly.

The Rev. Father at the same time, pointed out that the school was on the bank of the Belly River, and was liable to be flooded out. He suggested removal to higher ground. I told him that was a matter of consideration, and when it was decided what to do, we would decide where we would give assistance, and to what extent.

The Rev. Father also brings to my attention
Ottawa, October 7, 1906.

The Deputy Superintendent General:

The Principal of the Blood Roman Catholic school claims that he is entitled to more money than he has received on account of the earnings of this school. Forty pupils are already provided for and the Department has paid for this number. The Commissioner writing under date of the last inst. stated that through an error the Principal was informed more than a year ago that the grant had been provided for fifty pupils. He admits that a mistake was made and he would like the Department to help him out of the difficulty.

This can only be done by paying for the number shown to be in attendance under fifty and, if funds can be spared, I would suggest that the Department pay the amount claimed as earned by the school, about $250.00 up to the end of June, last, and continue payment for fifty pupils in future.

It would hardly do to let the impression go abroad that the Commissioner had not kept faith with the school authorities. Few, if any, of these mistakes have been made in the Commissioner's office.

[Signature]

Ottawa, October 8, 1906.

The Deputy Superintendent General,-

In regard to Father Salaun's statements to the Minister I beg to say that the Commissioner admits that through an error he advised him that fifty pupils had been provided for from April 1, 1907, while forty were all for whom the grant was provided.

The Department has never paid for more than forty, although the returns received since that date show the attendance to have been in excess of that number. No decrease was made in the grant but the increase of ten pupils asked for was not allowed and until it is authorized the Department will have to pay at the rate specified in the estimates.

The school is responsible for the location of the buildings and if the site is unsuitable it is the Church authorities that are to blame.

As to the unpaid bills for repairs and improvements, Father Salaun was officially informed on July 27, last, that it would be hardly possible to pay for the unauthorized expenditure on repairs, as the Department is required to deal strictly with such matters, the requirements of each school being specially estimated and
and provided for and those persons having direct supervision of repairs or additions to buildings are expected to limit themselves to the amounts specially authorized for such purpose. It is the rule of the Department that unauthorized expenditure is not recognized and the schools are well aware of this rule, which if not enforced would soon lead to reckless extravagance which no Government would be willing to meet.

[Signature]

Martin Benson

I receive notice just now that the question concerning the boarding school at Blood River have been settled. That is, the grant for thirty years has been granted, and the unsettled accounts have been paid.

I thank you very much for this.

As to the new plan and also the new estimates you asked me forward to you on November last. I beg to say that it was impossible for me to do so, owing to Reverend Father Grandin's absence, but I saw him last summer and he told that he was quite willing to do his share in regard to the removing and rebuilding of this Blood boarding...
school... The Rt. Father Grandin is the superior Provincial of the Oblate order, residing at Edmonton. I saw the Bishop of Saint Albert also; he told me again to wait, he was to talk to you about certain matters, he said, then he would be in a better position to tell me what was to be done.

Now, I tell you again what I told you the day I met you at the field. It would simply waste money to repair the present building, and if you don't think it expedient to have the building removed and rebuild, I better wait till all the concerned parties are all willing to do their share for the purpose. I don't want to work for nothing, and I don't want the department to spend the money for nothing.

I will simply suggest this that you give us a liberal grant so that we have a good start to put up a new building that will accommodate fifty pupils and we will manage so to get through successfully.

In the department, you have experts able to figure these estimates very well. Just now, I couldn't do
any better than that.

Expecting that you pay due consideration,

I remain

very honourable sir,

your respectful servant

J.M. Salter

MEMORANDUM:

Deputy Superintendent General.

I have read the attached letter from Father Salaun with reference to the R.C. Boarding School on the Blood Reserve. It is true as he states that the pupilage grant is now for 50 pupils, and a few outstanding accounts about which there was a difference of opinion have been paid. We have provided nothing to assist in the erection of a new building for this institution. As you are aware, we have not in the past assumed the full responsibility of Boarding School buildings and in the present unsettled condition of the School question, it seems impossible to do anything more than note the application.

Sir,

I beg to present my regular monthly medical report for April/09.

The R.C. Boarding School visited the same days. No cases of sickness in the school during the month. The St. Paul Mission School visited by me 4, 11, 18 and 29th. The general health of the school has been affected by the fact that last summer the flood destroyed the garden and there has consequently not been a full supply of vegetables through the winter months. No potatoes, beans mostly, and in this same school where for 2 years there was not a single case of sickness 3 years ago there has been in the past 6 months a decided tendency to scrofulous sores and enlarged glands.

Yours respectfully,

O.O. Edwards, M.D.,
Medical Officer.

DEPT. OF INDIAN AFFAIRS,
JAN 21 1915
ARCHITECT.
MEMORANDUM.

Mrs. Scott—

The Indian Boarding School on the Blood reserve, has recently made application for an additional 10 pupils supplementing the 50 pupils which the school is now entitled to, and for which they have provided ample dormitory accommodation.

The building is the property of the school authorities, and consists of a central building three stories high, with a two story wing at each end, and, was erected about 17 years ago. The construction is of balloon frame, erected on stone foundation, and while maintained in fair condition, is showing evident signs of deterioration, and will necessarily have to be replaced within a few years by a modern building.

The school is of C class, and without modern sanitary equipment or conveniences.
The additional dormitory accommodation is provided by utilizing two rooms in the third flat of main building formerly used for the staff, having a combined area of 11,284 cubic feet, or accommodation for 22 pupils, being more than double the required air space.

There is only one staircase leading to this upper flat, and it will, therefore, be necessary to provide a fire-escape from each of the upper dormitory rooms, for safe egress in case of fire.

The correspondence in reference to this matter shows that the number there could be recruited to 80 without difficulty, providing there was accommodation, and as this school is doing thoroughly, the work for which it was established, I would recommend that they be granted the additional 10 pupils which they request, on condition that satisfactory fire-escapes be erected.

Architect.

MAY REPORT OF AGENT BILWORTH.

BLOOD R.C. BOARDING SCHOOL.

I was disappointed in the class of instruction given and being given in the subjects, reading, arithmetic spelling. The children's work was merely memory work and did not appear to be developing any deductive power, altogether too parrot-like and lacking in expression. The English spoken is not clear.

Generally speaking the show side of actual school work is being emphasized too much to the detriment of the common branches of reading, writing, arithmetic and spelling and as a result the work does not give evidence of developing and deductive power or independence of thought. The English spoken is not good English.

Rv E. Rumsey,
Principal

Rev. Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 2nd instant in which you take exception to the report of Mr. Agent Dilworth on the class instruction given in your school and state that you are not at all surprised at such a report and that you do not attach the least importance to it.

You were informed of his criticism of the teaching at your school in order that you might take steps to correct the method complained of. As you have mentioned Mr. Inspector Markle's name in connection with this matter I beg to quote you an extract from his last inspection report on your school.— "The pupils in both the Jr. and Sr. class rooms speak more audibly than those in the C. of E. school, still there is room for improvement even here in this respect. The junior teacher allows her pupils to recite together as a class and then individually. This manner of procedure tends, I think, to offset the pupils' natural timidity and to encourage them to speak in higher tones. They are, however, liable to acquire a tendency to 'sang' tones when reading by this method. Some progress."

Dear Sir,

The trials herein are fixed for Monday morning the 16th instant at 10 o'clock in the morning. It seems that Colin MacLeod has been retained by the Indians themselves and as he stated in court this morning he had been paid to look after the Defence. REPORT OF INSPECTOR J.A. MARPLE ON THE BLOOD R.C. EDG. SCHOOL.

13. Black Rabbit and Rabbit Tail, school graduates, gained admittance to the girls dormitory about the 1st of August last and at about 2 O.C. in the night. The sister in charge of the dormitory attempted to cut off their retreat but these lads made their escape through the window by which they entered and where they had placed a ladder. There was a complaint made to the N.W.M. Police and the boys were arrested and on trial pleaded guilty.

I understand, to the charge. I was told that an item appeared in the local newspaper to the effect that Mr. Fawcett of Fawcett and Cameron, claimed at the trial that he was looking after the defense of the culprits in behalf of the Department. Rather Ruaux seemed to be passed over this report. He entertained the view that "the Department employed counsel it would look better in print if it did so to prosecute instead of to defend for such a case - an offence."

I afterwards looked over the office file for information on this point and found a letter to the Agent a copy of which I shall attach. Mr. Dilworth informed me that as far as he knew the Department had given no instructions to Mr. Fawcett. I found, however, that $60.52 had been paid, $55.00 fees and $5.52 costs, through the office and charged to a relation of one of the boys. Mr. Macleod accepted a horse worth about $75.00 for his claim.

Date of Inspection - November 5th, 1915

Sir,

Referring to your letter of 26th ultimo

No. 180148—I re supposed engagement of an attorney on behalf of the Indian Department to defend Peter Black Rabbitt and Peter Rabbit Tail; I beg to inform you that Mr Fawcett had no authority to say that he was engaged by the Indian Department;—He was engaged by Bruised Head the father of Peter Rabbitt Tail with my consent, and I do not believe Mr Fawcett that ever thought he was in any way employed by the Indian Department, what he said being wrongly interpreted by a reporter.

An attorney was engaged on behalf of Peter “Abb” Tail for the reason that he was not the real culprit and he was charged with a crime that would bring a sentence out of all proportion to the offence. The real culprit was Black Rabbitt and a large measure of blame for the offence rests with the School authorities themselves in allowing this boy to hang around the mission. He has been a pet of the R C and St Joseph’s Industrial school and is the boy whom the school St Joseph’s Industrial allowed out on leave of absence at 17 years of age until he should receive his discharge; attention to this fact was drawn to the Department by my letter of February 6th last, so that I felt justified in seeing that Peter Rabbitt Tail should not receive where punishment another boy was the real culprit.

The principal of the Blood R C school knows
knows that the Indian Department did not engage a lawyer to look after the defence of the boys in question. He knows that Peter Rabbitt Tail paid for his own lawyer out of wages earned by himself.

In cases like these I endeavor to see that our Indians get justice in the Courts, and that the sentences imposed are commensurate with the crime and the conditions governing them. I am ready to accept responsibility for the boy Peter Rabbitt Tail as for the other boy he should have received a heavier sentence than he did receive. It will probably have a beneficial effect on the school authorities too, as it will have a tendency to put a stop to favoritism.

I have the Honor to be

Sir

Your Obedient Servant

Indian Agent

REPORT OF INSPECTOR MARSH ON THE BLOOD R.C.E.D.G. SCHOOL.

REPORT DATED,- FEBRUARY 6th, 1917.

I HAVE SOMETIMES THOUGHT THAT THE MINDS OF THE CHILDREN were too much engrossed in the society doings on the reserve to give the attention to their studies that is necessary to make rapid advancement. The pupils at both of the schools here are in too close touch with reserve events, I think.
Ottawa, February 20th, 1917.

Sir,

In your recent report on the Blood R.C. boarding school, it is noted that you state that you consider that the children are too much engrossed in what is being done on the reserve and as a result they do not give sufficient attention to their studies.

Can you suggest any means by which this difficulty could be overcome?

Your obedient servant

Assistant Deputy and Secretary.

J.A. Markle, Esq.
Inspector of Indian Agencies,
Red Deer, Alberta.
Sir,

I have the honour to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 20th ultimo and to say that about the same conditions prevail where schools are located on reserves and where Indians have inherited the dance craze. The Superior of the Crowfoot School made a like complaint to me last Monday. She stated that the big boys apparently though of little else and were constantly running away from the school to attend these dances, of which there has been two and three weekly on this reserve—Blackfoot, since the payments of cash for grain about December 15th last, anyway.

I am unable to reply to your question to my own satisfaction.

Yours obediently,

[Signature]

Insp.

The Secretary,

Department of Indian Affairs,

Ottawa.
R.C. Boarding School, Stand-Off, Jan. 23rd, 1919.

To the Honourable D. Scott,
Superintendent of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

519187

Honourable Sir,

Mr. S. Middleton, principal of St. Paul's Mission, Church of England on the Blood Indian Reserve, told me, a few weeks ago the result of a conversation he had with you, at Ottawa last summer, about an increase of grant for the Indian Schools, and which you could not afford to give. But instead you suggested to him to solicit the Indians of the Reserve called in a special meeting to consent and to vote a certain sum, that would be paid by the Indian Department, out of the Reserve funds, to the two Schools of the Blood Reserve viz: the Church of England and the Roman Catholic, in order to help them to meet the high cost of living, and pass through the present hard times.

Mr. Middleton requested my assistance to prepare the Indians for the meeting by explaining the proposition to them before hand. I have no doubt that the Indians would willingly come to the help of the schools.

The aim, Honourable Sir, of the present letter, is to ascertain myself if you are still in favour of the plan suggested to Mr. Middleton last summer, I would like to receive the assurance of it directly from your hand, before taking any further step in that line.

Respectfully yours,

[Signature]
February 7, 1919.

Reverend Sir,

I am in receipt of your letter of the 23rd of January. I think that the present would not be an opportune time to submit any question to the Blood Indians with reference to expenditure on education, and, whenever it is thought advisable to do so, the proposition should be made by a representative of the Department.

I recollect discussing the matter with Mr. Middleton and expressing the view that the Blood Indians might expend some of their own money on the education of their children.

Yours very truly,

Rev. E. Riaux, C.M.I.,
Principal,
Roman Catholic Boarding School,

Extract from Inspector's report on the BLOOD R? C?

BOARDING SCHOOL, October 5, 1923.

Sister Gertrude, Elementary certificate, Illinois State Normal School.

Sister Mary, No certificate.

In the senior room there are 24 pupils enrolled, 11 in grade II, and 13 in grade IV. All are retarded, as may easily be inferred from the fact that IV is the highest grade in the school. In Grades I and II there are 36 pupils enrolled. They are also very backward.

Sister Gertrude succeeds in getting her class through the reading lesson by half pronouncing the word the pupil following up and appending the tails. In this manner each pupil reads once and then the class is dismissed. Spelling is taken orally, each pupil getting one word to spell. In arithmetic in Grade III the method is to call the class. All face the front of the room, then the teacher goes to the side board and sets down this question:

One pupil is sent to the board to work the problem. He multiplies aloud setting down the figures as he does so. His position is such that the rest of the class cannot observe what he is doing without turning around. And this they do not do, and hence take no more part than do the inhabitants of Mars. The Grade IV arithmetic problem was to divide 281973 by 3. As the pupil who was sent to the board to solve this problem did not know the table of three times he was given a card having all of the multiplication tables conveniently printed upon it and with this he managed with considerable help from the teacher to at last complete the problem.

Sister Mary's instruction is defective in every respect. Class management, supervision, assignments and methods of presenting the work are almost without exception lamentably poor.

J. H. Hutchison, Insp.
Ottawa, Apr. 9, 1923.

Reverend Sir:

I have to inform you that the Provincial Public School Inspector has reported so unfavourably concerning the instruction and teaching ability of Sister Gertrude and Sister Mary, of the Senior and Junior Rooms at the Blood R.C. Indian Boarding School, that it is my duty to ask you to arrange for better qualified successors in the near future. This Department's aim is to have efficient classroom instruction in the schools that are supported by parliamentary appropriation, and I should be pleased to have your cooperation. Please let me know what action you take in this connection.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Aset. Deputy & Secretary.

Rev. E. Ruaux, O.M.I.,
Principal,

W. M. Graham, Esq.,
Indian Commissioner,
Regina, Sask.
Dear Mr. Scott:

I have just returned from the Province of Alberta, where I have been for nearly three weeks. I visited the Blood, Peigan, Sarcee, Blackfoot, Hobbema and Edmonton Agencies, and eight Indian Boarding Schools.

BLOOD RESERVE.

I visited the Roman Catholic Blood School, which is situated on this Reserve. There are eleven Sisters in this Institution and between sixty and seventy children. As usual, I found the children in excellent shape - clean, well dressed and tidy. This was not a dress parade. The children are well fed and good work is being done here. This work, however, is being carried on under great disadvantages. The present school building is certainly unfit to carry on work in. However, the time is not far distant I hope, when they will enjoy a new building; and when it is built and operated, it will be a credit to the Indian Department. The work they are now doing under great disadvantages would be discouraging to most people. As it is, I found everything in the old building immaculate. They want to do a little brightening up of the interior of the classroom and livingroom, and asked to be allowed to have a little paint to do this work. I gave the Agent the necessary authority to purchase a small quantity of paint. The vouchers for this will pass through this office.

(Sgd.) W.M. Graham,
Indian Commissioner.

D.C. Scott, Esq.,
Deputy Supt. General of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Honourable Sir,

I am in receipt of your cheque amount $348.00 as a refund for the expenses made by our Sisters during the Summer Course at the University of Edmonton. I am very grateful to you for your kindness and generosity. More than ever, we realize the great interest you take in the education of Indian children, by helping to get for them better qualified teachers. Ours have greatly profited by the Course of the University, and the children entrusted to their care will also benefit by the knowledge they have acquired. Many thanks.

I am, Honourable Sir,

Respectfully yours,
Ottawa, February 3, 1925.

Reverend Sir:

I regret to inform you that the Provincial Public School Inspector has reported unfavourably concerning the language of Sister Gabriel Lafleur, the teacher of the junior room at the Blood R.C. Indian Residential School. I am aware that this teacher took a special course in Edmonton this summer; but it will take considerable time for her to overcome her handicap in English. It is of vital importance that the teachers of Indian children have a good command of the language of instruction and I shall be pleased if you will arrange in the immediate future for a better qualified instructor. Please let me know what action you take in this connection.

Your obedient servant,

Mr Russell T. Ferrier,
Superintendent of Education
Department of Indian Affairs
OTTAWA, Ont.

My Dear Mr Ferrier:

I just returned this morning from a visit to both the Peigan and Blood Schools. On our way south we had stopped at Hobbema and visited Erminaskins' school. Rev. Fr Blanchin and myself enjoyed our trip and for my part I feel very pleased to give you the very best news about the construction of the new Blood School which is progressing rapidly and under ideal circumstances.

In connection with this reconstruction of the Blood School I wish to have instructions regarding the management of the new school. Commissioner Graham has stated to Rev. Fr Ruaux Principal that he was to be in full charge instead of the Sisters who until now were responsible to the Department though correspondence was exchanged with Rev. Fr Ruaux only. The latter together with Rev. Fr Blanchin are in favor of the change and the Sisters seem also to prefer it though the higher administration has not as yet sanctioned the change. Would you kindly give me your idea in this matter even by wire if possible.

A matter arising from the change of possession is that of stock and farm implements. Mr Graham stated to Rev. Fr Ruaux that the Department would supply farm implements but not stock to the new school. Rev. Fr Ruaux is conversant with the fact that the Department has supplied stock to different schools in similar circumstances and does not know what to make out of the Commissioner's statement. So he has requested me to ask from you about the Department's policy.

Another matter is that of the accounts. Rev. Fr Ruaux wishes to know if his school is on the same basis and of the same character as that of Duck Lake and if therefore accounts are to be kept in the same manner.

As I will be at the above address until the 11th I would be grateful to you for sending me a wire covering all the above matters.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

St. Mary's R.C. Residential School Blood Reserve
Cardston Alta. July 2nd, 1926

To the Honorable D.C. Scott
Depute Minister
Ottawa

Honorable Sir,

I feel it my duty to express my gratitude for the erection of a new Roman Catholic Residential School on the Blood Reserve. You have treated us with great generosity, in giving us a splendid construction equipped with all modern conveniences. In my own name and that of the Blood Indians of our Creed, I thank you with all my heart. I have no doubt that this School will prove a great factor in advancing the work we are doing among the Indians.

As we shall have the official opening of this new Institution on July 21st, I should feel highly favored if you could be present for the occasion, which would give the Indians an opportunity of expressing their appreciation of your interest.

Most respectfully yours,

[Signature]
July 9, 1926.

Reverend and dear Sir,

I have your letter of the 2nd instant, informing me that the new school building will be opened on the 21st July. I should consider myself fortunate if it were possible for me to be present at the opening and to inspect the new building, and to see yourself and the staff in your new quarters, but I regret that under the present circumstances that would be impossible. However, I should like to send a message of congratulation on the continuance of your activities in surroundings so greatly improved, and to bespeak for you continued success. On my early visits to the Blood Reserve I resolved that the school buildings should be modernized as soon as possible, and in this resolve I was supported by the Honourable the Superintendent General, and Parliament generously granted us the necessary funds for the purpose. I feel that the new institution is in excellent hands, and that you will make as full as possible use of the equipment to promote the interest and progress of the Indians of the Blood Reserve.

Yours faithfully,

Deputy Superintendent General.

Rev. E. Ruaux, O.M.I.
St. Mary's Roman Catholic Residential School,
Cardston, Alberta.
St. Mary's R.C. Residential School Blood Reserve
Cardston Alta. July 2nd, 1926

Mr. Duncan Scott,
Depute Minister,
Ottawa

Honorable Sir,

In making the returns for the quarter ending June 30th, 1926, I have calculated the per capita grant on the basis of one hundred and sixty-five Dollars (165) per annum; I have done this in order that our school may be given the same assistance as institutions of equal standard. Schools of the same standard were automatically accorded the increased grant upon removal to their new buildings, and there seem no reason why this school should not be treated in the same manner. Since the first of April I have taken over the administration of the school from the sisters, and am in pressing need of funds owing to extraordinary expenses consequent upon the opening of the new school.

I am Honorable Sir,

Respectfully yours,

[Signature]
Ottawa, July 14, 1926.

Dear Father Ruaux:

I have your letter of the 2nd instant, with reference to the per capita grant to be allowed this fiscal year in the case of the Blood Indian Residential School.

I regret that the funds at our disposal this year are extremely limited and it will not be possible to provide any increases at present. I intend to bring the varied needs of the educational institutions to the attention of the Honourable the Superintendent General at the earliest opportunity; but it will be impossible to immediately augment the per capita grant.

Best wishes for a successful official opening on the 21st of the month.

Yours very truly,

Duncan C. Scott

Deputy Superintendent General.

Blood N.C. Residential School,

May 28th 1927.

Honorable Mr. Scott,
Dept. of Indian Affairs.

By a letter dated May 3rd, Mr. Ferrier informed me that the grant of our School had been increased to $155.00 per capita. Lately the Rev. Fr. Beys, our Provincial Superior, wrote to me saying that Mr. Ferrier had informed him that our grant was raised to $160.00, but that he had made application to you to obtain for our school the same grant as the one allowed to the Duck Lake school, viz., $170.00.

Moreover I am informed that the grant at the St Paul's school, Blood Reserve, is $160.00 since this new school was opened two years ago. There would seem to be a discrimination against our new school, which nevertheless is located on the same Reserve but further away from the Cardston Railway Station than St Paul's.

Although I appreciate the increase granted, still I hope that our school will not be treated inferiorly than others under similar conditions.

Yours respectfully,

E. Ruaux, O.M.I.
Principal.
June 7, 1927.

Dear Father Ruaux:

I have your letter of the 28th ultimo, with reference to the grant allowed in the case of the Blood Indian Residential School. It is true that there are some temporary inequalities in the amount of grant allowed to Indian residential schools in the Prairie Provinces. These are being removed as fast as possible. An adjustment commenced the beginning of this fiscal year. Some time ago the St. Paul's Institution applied for and received a larger grant than paid formerly. At that time the present adjustment was not contemplated, as it was uncertain whether or not funds for the purpose would be provided by Parliament. This year the Blood School received an increase of $15 and the St. Paul's School, no increase. I am hopeful that in the near future it will be possible to have both schools at the rate contemplated for institutions of this type and in this geographical situation, viz.: $170. I regret that funds are not available at the present time to pay more than $155 per capita in the case of your school.

Yours very truly,

J. D. McLean,
Acting Deputy Superintendent General.

Rev. E. Ruaux, O.M.I.,
Principal,
Blood Indian Res. School,
Cardston, Alta.

Roman Catholic Residential School,
Cardston, Alta., January 23, 1928.

Honorable D.C. Scott, Deputy Minister,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Canada.

Statement requested by Mr. Pugh, Indian Agent, Blood Reserve, Alta.
Re: Smith and Albert Many Fingers.

Honorable Sir:

My occupation at the R.C. School, Blood Reserve, is the one of Gardiner in summer time. During the winter months, sharing the work with the Disciplinarian and assisting in the Boiler room. Albert Many Fingers, is a Pupil 17 years of age.

Trouble between myself and this boy commenced about two months ago. Specific orders had been given by the Reverend Principal E. Ruaux, that the boys should not pass through the corridors, leading along side the kitchen to the Boiler room. Albert Many Fingers took no heed of the order and continued without any good reason, to appear into these passages. I repeatedly cautioned him, at the beginning, in as a friendly a way as was possible to do, what he had been told; I had to the present time a good opinion of the boy and wanted by all means to prevent trouble, but he took no notice whatever; on the contrary, began to show outward signs of antagonism towards me. It gradually seemed to me that an attempt was being made by my authority. Every time he would meet me, he would show signs of contempt and defiance sneering at my face occasionally using such insults as no white man would take from another; not speaking of an Indian, until he gave me clearly to understand, that I was afraid of him and that he was going to fight and lick me, as in fact, he had told another senior boy, Willie Mills by name, whom he wanted to lead in the same trouble and whose statement you will find here enclosed.

It would take too much space to relate in detail the different times and happenings in which this boy brought himself into trouble, in these passages. The sole reason for doing so was to have a chance to flirt with the girls working in the kitchen, laundry, creamery, bakery, etc. He was caught many times at this game and actually once, acting indecently, in company of the afore named Willie Mills, with one of the big girls. The whole staff was taking notice of this situation and the sisters in charge of the girls complained to me, that through the actions of these two boys, the entire girls were becoming uncontrollable. In the dining room, their pastime was to talk and make signs to one another, which obliged me to change these two boys' places, where they could be better seen. It brought the matter to its climax and I went again to the Rev. Principal, who was already aware of everything and who had given strong warning to Albert Many Fingers, that he was getting himself in bad trouble. Rev. Father Ruaux answered me that it would not settle the question, if he would strap the boy, but would rather increase his contempt for me, for having him punished and would incite him to come back on me at first opportunity. I must have my own authority and use it when necessary, as the Rev. Principal absents himself occasionally.

I had stood all I could from that boy. He wanted to fight me and I had to meet him on his own grounds. The boy is 17 years old and considers himself a man; so on the following Monday morning, when the pupils were going to breakfast, I kept him back in the play room. I pointed
out to him his conduct towards me, his disobedience, his insults and finally told that since he thought himself a better man than I, the time has arrived to show it. He was given the same chance that I had myself. I hit him a few times and the result was a bleeding nose. When I saw that he was making no attempt at striking back, I quit, mentioned again the friendliness I had shown towards him in the past, pointed out to him what was right for his own good and took him to breakfast.

The matter would have had stopped right there, if the boy had not run away from the School, taking away another boy, and told the Indians he met all kinds of lies about what had taken place, such as stating that the School teacher Mr. Coady was holding his hands behind his back while I was pounding his face and creating an uproar on the whole Reserve. The fact is that Mr. Coady coming down for breakfast, knowing that all the Pupils were already in the dining room and hearing talking in the play room, opened the door, walked in, stood there and remained at least ten or twelve feet from the boy at all times and left before the thing was over.

A few days later, the Agent Mr. Pugh, I understand, came to the School to make an investigation. I was not home at the time. He took the boy's evidence and more or less past judgement on me without even giving me a hearing, to which I take exception, giving those present to understand that if I do this again, I would be turned out of the School. I am not appealing to you for support, for this position I am holding. I have since coming here been offered better and more remunerative positions. I am only staying here with the idea of service. Helping where help is needed, may explain it better. What I do want and expect, is justice and also respect and obedience from those in my charge, which, if I could not obtain by myself, I would not consider myself eligible for the position. I have worked at boys work for many years and was Scout Master of a troop in Lethbridge before coming here. In my opinion, all this trouble could have been avoided, had the Agent, the father of the boy, and the Principal of the School, got together and talked the matter over. It was nothing more than what happens daily in all Indian schools, I understand. In fact, I have been informed of much greater trouble at the other School on this Reserve, when the Disciplinarian was knocked down by a boy with a piece of scantling on the head, and the staff held at bay by the same boy with a drawn knife; things similar to this would have happened in this particular case, had it not been checked in time, the way it was. These extreme means, must meet these extreme situations, it is the only method. A man has to protect his rights, himself, his good name and the good name of his mother. A mountain has been made out of a mole hill, in this case.

Trusting you and Mrs. Scott are in the best of health, believe me to be, Honorable Sir.

Respectfully yours

[Signature]

C.J. Smith
Sir,

I beg to confirm my night lettergram of Jan. 26th, and to acknowledge receipt of your wire of Jan. 21st, and in reference to this matter I wish to submit herewith my report.

On January 5th a fight took place at the R.C.School, Blood Reserve, this was reported to me on the 14th inst., in the meantime on the 10th, Father Ruaux had reported to me that two boys had truanted including Albert Many Fingers. The father of the boy came to see me on Saturday the 14th inst., and as Agent asked my assistance in the matter, at the same time declaring his intention of having the charge laid against Assistant Smith for assault. In order to avoid trouble but the mothers of the two boys came to my office Monday and I personally took them to the St. Mary's School to look into the matter. The Chief who was at the office, expressed his desire to be present and this was granted by myself. At the school it was found that Mr. Smith was absent on leave, and I asked for Father Ruaux and the boys to state their case, this was done so.

The stories vary somewhat, but in the main it is admitted that there was an invitation to fight and a fight did take place, and it is admitted that the boy's nose was bleeding. While dealing with the matter, I stated that the Department, as far as I knew, would not countenance the striking of a boy by fists, and stated that I thought the proper method should be by the use of a regulation strap and that, in the event of a further case arising, I would report to the Department and ask for the dismissal of any Teacher or Disciplinearian using his fists. I came away from the school and I was under the impression that the matter was finished there; however, the Chief and father came to see me later and were insistent in their desire to have this man prosecuted and they requested me to send my lettergram to you. At this time Mr. Inspector Christianson was present at this Agency and the father of the boy took this matter up with him, and Mr. Christianson and myself discussed the matter and decided to wire you for instructions.

On receipt of your wire I proceeded to the school Saturday evening to convey your information to Father Ruaux. Father Ruaux, Mr. Smith and Mr. Cody were present and, much to my astonishment, found Father Ruaux and Mr. Smith in an antagonistic frame of mind and, among many things, said was, that it was unfair to pass judgment and wire yourself without me getting a statement from Mr. Smith. I therefore was not insistent in prosecuting your telegram and asked Mr. Smith to let me have a written statement to forward to you.

This statement

Duncan C. Scott, Esq.,
Deputy Superintendent General of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ontario.
This statement is attached and speaks for itself.

Father Ruaux, in his statement to me at the school, took exception to my being allowed to investigate this matter, and accuses me of the following things. First, that I took a lot of Indians to the school at the time when I first investigated this, but not before him that I was coming, but put the two Indians in question in my car and drove to the school. The Chief went by himself; at the school there was as a matter of fact, a number of Indians when I arrived. Secondly, he accuses me of being partisan for the reason that they are Catholics. He states that he will endeavour to have an Agent's duties confined to looking after the plant only; that they could not manage the children with the Agent and the Inspector listening to complaints from Indians and then proceeding to the school to investigate. He states further that this had to be done in the case of Nurses and that Mr. Inspector Christianson had been reported along the same lines. Father Ruaux states he would not accept an investigation by Inspector Christianson, but only from some one from the Ottawa office, and that he would have to have his Superior, and if necessary the Bishop, present at the investigation. I might say that at an Indian dance, to which this boy was away to, this matter was announced to the Indians assembled, this information I have obtained from the father and the boy. Lastly, I am accused of taking action on the lies of Indians as is the case always and making, as contained in Mr. Smith's letter, a mountain out of a mole hill.

The Chief came to see me again Monday the 23rd inst., and again repeated his interest in the matter and stated, that if the Department did not take some action against Mr. Smith that they would still ask the Police to do so. I might say that the father of the boy has already laid the information in this case, but they have been asked to withhold action.

In regard to Mr. Smith's statement, this speaks for itself. It includes the admission of inviting to fight and fighting, but is tempered with the defence that it is necessary. The argument is in this connection given by Father Ruaux and Mr. Smith, that with Indians of this type unless they are humiliated no good can be done with them.

In regard to my action in this case, or in any other school case, I have always governed myself by that form of instructions to Indian Agents under your signature found on pages eight and nine under Educational clauses 28 & 29, which speaks for themselves. Father Ruaux contends that an Agent has not the right to look into matters of this kind, and that I have no right whatever of stating that a strap could be used. It appears to me that if such a condition as having to fight, no matter what the provocation may be unless actual self defense, has not a place in conducting schools or Agencies in our Department. I do not think that you would tolerate for one minute myself or any of the staff lowering themselves to fisticuffs with the Indians no matter what the offence, unless actual self defense, and I know that we should be immediately dismissed.

In conclusion I wish to state, that in view of the conditions existing in matters of this kind, and particularly in this case, I wish to tentatively place my resignation in your hands on the basis of the accusations made against me, and the fact that this will make it practically impossible for cooperation with Father Ruaux, especially so will this be the case should an Agent be instructed not to visit the schools from a disciplinerian or other point of view.

I have always
I have always considered it my duty in a complaint of this kind to investigate and the one failure, that of courtesy in not phoning Father Ruaux previous to my leaving the office, is probably regrettable. I am rendering this report unbiased and would ask for a thorough investigation into this matter.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Indian Agent.
4th February, 1928.

Dear Mr. Pugh,

I have your letter of January 25th with enclosure. The incident is giving me some concern. I would not receive your resignation even in any qualified sense. You must continue to administer the agency firmly, with a full knowledge that you have the confidence and support of the Department.

In view of Mr. Smith's unwarranted assault of this pupil as corroborated by his own statement and the refusal of the principal to dismiss him or to do anything else to recognize the injury done to this boy, I do not feel warranted in asking the father of the boy to further refrain from prosecuting the charge already laid against Mr. Smith. You will advise the father accordingly that he is at liberty to take whatever course to him may seem proper.

Yours truly,

Duncan C. Scott

Deputy Superintendent General.

J.E. Pugh, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Cardston, Alta.
February 7, 1928.

Reverend Sir,

I am informed by the Indian Agent for the Blood Reserve, who has general supervision over the residential schools and all other activities on the reserve, that you have objected to his investigating the conduct of Mr. E. J. Smith, an employee of the school, and that you stated that you would endeavour to have his duties confined to looking after the mechanical and material part of the school; that this action had to be taken in the case of nurses, and that our inspectors have been reported for similar action; and that you stated that you would not accept an inspection by Inspector Christianson; and that you would have your Superior, and if necessary, the Bishop, present at an investigation.

I have to ask you for an immediate explanation of this statement. I have every confidence in Agent Pugh, and I take a serious view of the statements that he has made.

Yours very truly,

Duncan C. Scott

Deputy Superintendent General.

Rev. H. Ruaux, O.M.I.,

Crime Report

Re: Edwin Smith - Cardston Alta.- Common Assault

On the 26th inst., Morris Many Fingers, an Indian of the Blood Reserve, came to this Detachment & complained that on the 5th inst., his son Albert, age 17 years, a pupil of the Roman Catholic School on this Reserve, had been assaulted by the above named, who is one of the staff at the above mentioned school.

The affair took place at the school, which is situated on the Blood Indian Reserve. The following is a brief outline of what happened:

It appears that for some time past Albert Many Fingers had been disobeying certain regulations made by the Rev. Father E. Roux, the Principal of the school, and when spoken to about it by Smith, who assists the Disciplinarian during out-of-school hours, it is alleged he became insolent & it is further alleged that he had expressed his intention of fighting Smith at the first opportunity.

On the 5th inst., Albert Many Fingers was deliberately disobedient, which resulted in Smith, whose age is about 30, inviting the Indian boy to fight. Smith then hit him several times & made his nose bleed, without any retaliation whatsoever on the part of the Indian boy.

An information was laid on the 26th inst. by Morris Many Fingers before J.W. Low, Police Magistrate, charging Smith with violation of section 291 of the Criminal Code of Canada. In the meanwhile the Dept. of Indian Affairs, at Ottawa was notified of what had happened by J.E. Pugh, Indian Agent, and word was received from the Dept. to the effect that Smith was to be immediately dismissed. If this order is complied with by the Principal, Morris Many Fingers desires to withdraw the information, no doubt the Police Magistrate will allow this to be done, because if Smith is dismissed, he has been sufficiently punished.

From my investigation in this case, I understand that on the day in question Smith admits striking the Indian boy, and then makes a futile attempt to justify his actions, by saying that this was the only way to enforce obedience, which is obviously ridiculous. If Albert Many Fingers was disobedient & merited punishment, same should have been administered in the proper manner, i.e. the regulation strap. There are numerous legal rulings laid down, which support this contention.

A. Howard
Sgt
(A. Howard)
Reg. No. 4627
I/c. Cardston Detachment

Dear Mr. Scott:

In an interview I had yesterday with Rev. Father Ruaux, Principal of the Blood Indian School, he communicated to me the letter You addressed to him on the 7th inst. The Rev. Father asked me to answer to same, as he did not feel inclined to write on his own behalf.

I made a careful inquiry about the accusations brought against Father Ruaux, and, I think, I may safely state the following as the real facts:

1. Rev. Father Ruaux never objected to inspections or investigations from Department Officials. We could hardly expect anything else from a man who has been 18 years Principal of one of our biggest Schools and probably the most difficult to manage.

2. Rev. Father Ruaux objected to investigations or inspections as some have been conducted lately, both by Mr Christianson and Mr Pugh. If my informations are true, and I have every reason to believe they are, no one could blame the Principal for his objecting to same.

3. The mention about nurses was never made according to the statement of the school staff who assisted to the interview between Mr Pugh and the Principal.

4. It must be added that in the heat of the discussion, Rev. Father Principal may have said words that went beyond what he had really in mind. On the other hand his meaning may have been misunderstood. The sad fact remains that relations between the Agent and the Principal are strained. I am working to promote amongst them a better understanding and expect to be helped by the Department in this purpose, as no good can result without broad minded cooperation.

I am, dear Mr. Scott always Yours sincerely.

J. O.B. Beaton

Mr. DUNCAN C. SCOTT
Deputy Superintendent General
Department of Indian Affairs
Ottawa Ont.

Crime Report

No.: Edwin Smith - Cardston Alta. - Common Assault

With further reference to C.R., re the above dated 26-1-28 & 17-2-28, this case was proceeded with on the 25th inst. at Cardston before J.W. Lew Police Magistrate.

J.O'Brien, Barrister of Cardston for the Prosecution and G.E.A. Rice, Barrister of Lethbridge for the Defense.

The accused on being arraigned pleaded "Not Guilty". Evidence was given by Albert Many Fingers for the Prosecution, as outlined in C.R., re the above dated 26-1-28, which was corroborated by two other Indian boys named Jim Big Threat & Bob Big Soreel Horse.

At the close of the case for the Prosecution, Counsel for the Defense applied to His Worship for dismissal of the case against his client, pleading the provisions of section 65 of the Criminal Code in extenuation, but the Magistrate asked to hear the evidence for the Defense.

The accused in giving evidence on his own behalf, the sum & substance of which is that he admitted both inviting Albert Many Fingers to fight and striking him three or four times in the face with clenched fists, but claimed this was the only way to enforce discipline. Smith's evidence was corroborated by A.W. O'Conley, one of the teachers at the Indian School in question.

The Police Magistrate after considering the evidence both for the Prosecution & Defense, adjudicated as follows, using these words: "(1) I think that blows with clenched fists on the face is unreasonable punishment under the circumstances of this case; it would be justified only to resist force with force. (2) I think that the accused stepped outside the bounds of his official position, when he invited Albert Many Fingers to fight. This in my opinion was not discipline, I adjudge the accused, Edwin Smith, guilty of assault and impose a fine of $10.00 & costs or in default 10 days imprisonment in the Provincial Jail at Lethbridge. Fine & costs paid forthwith.

Before the court was closed the Counsel for the Defense intimated the possibility of an appeal being entered.

Sir,

I beg to confirm herewith my wire of today's date which reads as follows, "Smith was convicted for assault on Saturday, reporting fully".

In further reference to the matter, I respectfully wish to report on the case which I attended.

The Case came up before Police Magistrate Low, on Saturday at 2 PM. Mr. Smith was represented by Mr. G.E.A. Rice of Lethbridge, and Mary Fingers was represented by Mr. O'Brien of Cardston. The various witnesses were examined after giving evidence for the prosecution, and after the prosecution evidence was all taken, Mr. Rice moved for dismissal, on the grounds that that the punishment was not excessive and that it was necessary in the particular case, and went on further to say that the matter had no right to be in Court, but was a means of settling a dispute between the Principal of the School and the Indian Agent, and certainly would not have come up, if the Indian Agent had not interfered with the operation of the School. (I was not present in the Court Room when this was stated, being called out at the time the statement was made.) At this point Mr. O'Brien asked for permission to place me on the stand, which was deemed not advisable. Mr. O'Brien then demanded that the statement be retracted, which I understand was done. The Magistrate then called for the Defence witnesses, who were duly examined, Mr. Smith himself going on to the stand, and was cross-examined. After all parties had rested their cases, the Magistrate summed up the judgement in the following way, as his record reads as follows:

(1) I think that blows with clenched fists on the face unreasonable punishment under the circumstances of this case; it would be justified only to resist force with force.

(2) I think that the accused stepped outside the bounds of his official position when he invited Albert Mary Fingers to fight. This in my opinion was not discipline, I adjudge the accused, Edin Smith, guilty of assault. Penalty $10.00 and costs.

I do not know whether I am expected to make comment on the case, and will refrain from doing so unless the Department request such, I would, however, like to go on record as being absolutely aggrieved at the way I was injected into the matter by Smith's Counsel, especially in view of the fact, that Mr. Rice was taken to the School by Mr. Smith the evening previous to the case, and no doubt the Department will then see where such viscous opinion originated from, and I feel it my just right that an apology should come from that source through the Department for the statement made.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,
Your obedient servant,

Duncan C. Scott, Esq.,
Deputy Superintendent General,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

With further reference to previous C.Rs.re the above dated 26-1-28, 26-2-28, 29-2-28 & 30-3-28, on April 2nd, I patrolled in auto to Macleod to attend Court in the Appeal of the above mentioned case, which was tried at Macleod on the 3rd.inst, before His Honor Judge A.M.Macdonald.

J.D. Matheson, Agent for the Attorney General, at Macleod and J.W. O'Brien of Cardston for the Prosecution.

G.E.A. Rose of Shepherd, Rice & Fairbairn & Lethbridge for the Defense.

There was very little difference between the evidence produced by the Crown at this trial and that which was produced at the trial at Cardston in the Police Magistrate's court on February 25th last, with the exception that the Rev. W.K. Haynes of the Pelican Indian Reserve gave evidence at this trial, with regard to the usual method employed in Indian schools when it was necessary in the interests of discipline to chastise a pupil for misconduct, and told the Court that in his experience of 50 years teaching Indian boys, the chastising was always done by the Principal and with a strap and on examination by Counsel for the Defense stated that when the occasion demanded it he would resist force with force, or words to that effect.

Turning to the evidence produced by the Defense, this was practically the same as at the trial. An attempt was made by the Defense to introduce fresh evidence by calling an Indian boy by the name of Willie Mills to give evidence that he had heard Albert Many Fingers say he was going to fight him because he was too strict. But the memory of this witness when he got on the witness stand became confused and he forgot apparently what he was supposed to say.

The accused in giving evidence on his own behalf, in part stated that the only way to enforce discipline among Indian boys was to humiliate them by striking them in the face, and anywhere else did not have the desired effect, and went on further to say that it was useless to take them to the Principal for punishment, because by so doing he would lose authority over them. (If this is so, it would appear that there is something radically wrong in the management of the school in question as far as enforcing proper discipline is concerned.)

During this trial, the Judge in course of his remarks intimated that he would have liked to hear another witness who had considerable experience in enforcing discipline in Indian schools. Here I must mention that the Crown intended to subpoena Mr. T.K. Middleton, Principal of the St. Paul Anglican Indian School on the Blood Indian Reserve, but after I had inquired him about it, he positively declined to appear as witness.
unless he was compelled to, on account of the strained relationship between the Principal of the St. Mary's R.C. Indian school and himself, so under these circumstances it was deemed unadvisable to call him as witness.

As in previous cases His Honor showed his usual antipathy towards, and lack of patience with Indian witnesses for the Prosecution. He seems not to understand that it is very seldom Indians are conversant enough with the English language to give evidence without the aid of an interpreter. And furthermore I have no hesitation in saying that he showed a distinct leaning towards the Defense all through the trial of this Appeal.

In summing up the Judge said he was satisfied that Albert Many Fingers, in his opinion was a bad boy & deserved chastisement, but he was undecided whether or not Smith should have punished the boy the way he did. It was a very important case to decide, as it would a ruling for all other Indian schools in the district, and therefore he would reserve his decision until a later date.

................A. Howard... Sergt

SMITH WINS HIS APPEAL IN ASSAULT CASE

MAY 4 1928
IN THE DISTRICT COURT OF THE DISTRICT OF MACLEOD.

HIS MAJESTY THE KING?

-and-

EDWIN SMITH.

JUDGEMENT OF HIS HONOUR JUDGE MACDONALD.

The appellant Edwin Smith was convicted by J.W. Low, a Police Magistrate, on the 25th day of February last for unlawfully committing an assault on Albert Many Fingers, a pupil at St. Mary's Roman Catholic Indian School situated on the Blood Reserve south of Macleod.

Smith is employed on the staff of the School referred to and among his other duties is that of maintaining discipline among the pupils. During the absence of the principal he is in charge of the School.

Many Fingers is a pupil attending the School. He is a strong healthy boy and about the same height and weight as the appellant, and will be seventeen years old on the 5th of this month. Prior to the alleged assault he had been the cause of considerable trouble in the school and was a leader amongst some of the older pupils who were evidently becoming discontented at being subjected to school discipline. He had intimated his intention of fighting Smith. The appellant spoke to him about his conduct and also warned him but with no effect, as he continued to be insolent and disobedient to both Smith and his teacher. The appellant then reported the matter to the principal who advised him that it was his duty to see that discipline was maintained. He then concluded that in order to carry out his instructions and maintain discipline in the school it was necessary that he punish Many Fingers. On the morning of January 9th when the pupils were marching in to breakfast he requested him to stand out of line. When the other pupils had marched into the dining-room he told Many Fingers that he had been corrected several times but was still disobedient and he was now going to punish him, or words to that effect. He also referred to Many Fingers threat to fight him. Other words then passed between them and Many Fingers, seeing that he was about to be punished, assumed a fighting attitude with closed fists. Upon his so doing Smith struck him three rapid blows about the face and head with his fists causing his nose to bleed. Many Fingers then stepped back. No further attempt was made by Smith to strike him.
I find that the blows struck, although causing the pupil's nose to bleed, were not severe and caused no apparent bruise or discoloration of the flesh where struck.

I further find that the appellant in administering the punishment was not guilty of malicious intent or was he actuated by any ill-will towards Many Fingers. The punishment was not inflicted in a fit of anger.

Following the judgments of Rex vs Metcalfe (1927) 3 W.W.R. 194; Rex vs Zinck, 18 Canadian Criminal cases 456; Regina vs Robinson, 7 Canadian Criminal Cases 52, and the authorities therein cited, I think that the appellant had the right to punish the pupil in question, or any of the other pupils disobeying the rules of the School.

At the close of the hearing of this appeal considerable doubt existed in my mind as to whether or not the force used was reasonable under the circumstances.

I have carefully considered the evidence submitted on this point especially that of Rev. William R. Hanes, called by the crown, and who has had considerable experience in the management of Indian Schools. When asked what he would do if an Indian attempted to fight him he said he would knock him down and then take him to the principal to be dealt with.

I have further considered the fact that the pupil had boasted that he intended fighting the appellant and the further fact that in appearance at least, he was physically able to carry out his boast. These, with the further facts that he assumed a fighting attitude when approached by Smith, and that when Many Fingers stepped back after receiving the blows complained of, no further attempt was made by Smith to strike him, convinces me, after consulting a number of authorities on this point, that the force used was not under the circumstances unreasonable. In this regard I may refer to the words of Ouseley, D.C.J., in the case of Rex vs Hilton decided by him in March, 1919, (unreported) and quoted in Rex vs Metcalfe already referred to, which reads as follows: "It seems to me therefore that under these authorities I am in this appeal bound to find that taking into consideration the doctrine laid down in the case of State vs Pendergrass as explained by the case of Rex v Gaul that the force used was reasonable under the circumstances. I have consulted many authorities and so far as my reading extends the only case in which the schoolmaster or mistress has been found guilty of an assault is where the act was done with a dangerous weapon, improper for correction, and likely (the age and strength of the pupil being duly considered) to kill or maim, such as an iron bar, etc., or where the pupil is kicked on
the ground or otherwise ill-treated, or where the chastisement is flagrantly excessive, or the master has been actuated with malice or ill-will towards the pupil, but I have found no case which goes nearly the length that the respondent on this appeal is asking me to do, namely to hold that because a punishment inflicted by the schoolmistress caused temporary pain and discolouration of the flesh for a few days that no pain or inconvenience was experienced so far as the evidence shows outside the first two days, I should hold that the punishment inflicted was excessive or was not reasonable under the circumstances.

I think, after taking all the circumstances into consideration, that the language in this quotation applies in this case.

For the reasons submitted the appeal will be allowed with costs and the conviction quashed and set aside with costs.

"A.M. MacDonald"

May 2nd, 1928.

J.D.C.
Note re Grant.

Concerning the difference in the Govt. Grant to the Church of England and the Rom.Cath. Schools on the Bloods and Piegans Reserves, it may be pretexted that this increase (difference) is a compensation due to the Church of England for the moneys invested by them in their old Schools, before new moving into the new ones.

But no compensation was granted to the Rom.Cath. for their buildings or lands used in connection with the School, for years and years, such as was the case of the old School at Duck Lake, Sask.
RE PER CAPITA GRANT.

ST MARY'S R.C. INDIAN SCHOOL, CARDSTON, ALTA.

The present Grant is $155.00.

In a letter from Hon. D.C. Scott to Rev. Father Guy, dated Nov. 1927, an increase of $10.00 was intimated to act retroactively from July 1st 1927. So far no increase has been granted.

While the Anglicans since moving into the new St Paul's School three years ago have been receiving $165.00.

St Mary's School is laboring at least under the same financial difficulties, and it is hard to understand this discrimination, which seems like an unfair treatment.

SACRED HEART R.C. SCHOOL, BROCKET, ALTA.

RE: Edwin Smith—Common Assault

With reference to my previous crime report dated as marginally noted, re the above;

I beg to further report that Judge A.M. McDonald, of the District Court of the District of MacLeod, gave his judgment in writing last evening in connection with the above appeal, heard by him in the District Court Sitting commencing on the 3rd of April last. The appellant Edwin Smith was convicted by J.W. Low, a Police Magistrate, on the 25th day of February last for unlawfully committing an assault on Albert Many Fingers, a pupil at St. Mary's Roman Catholic Indian School situated on the Blood Reserve south of MacLeod. Smith was and is employed on the staff of the school referred to and among his other duties is that of maintaining discipline among the pupils. During the absence of the principal he is in charge of the school.

The facts of his honour's judgment are as follows:

"I find that the blows struck, although causing the pupil's nose to bleed, were not severe and caused no apparent bruise or discolouration of the flesh where struck. I further find that the appellant in administering the punishment was not guilty of malicious intent or was he actuated by any ill-will towards Many Fingers. The punishment was not inflicted in a fit of anger.

Following the judgments of Rex vs. Metcalfe (1927) S.W.W. 194; Rex vs. Sinck, 88 Canadian Criminal cases 456; Regina vs. Robinson, 7 Canadian Criminal Cases 58, and the authorities therein cited, I think that the appellant had the right to punish the pupil in question, or any of the other pupils disobeying the rules of the school.

At the close of the hearing of this appeal considerable doubt existed in my mind as to whether or not the force used was reasonable under the circumstances.

I have carefully considered the evidence submitted on this point, especially that of the Rev. William R. Haynes, called by the Crown, and who had considerable experience in the management of Indian Schools. When asked what he would do if an Indian attempted to fight him, he said "he would knock him down and then take him to the principal to be dealt with."

I have further considered the fact that the pupil had boasted that he intended fighting the appellant and the further fact that in appearance at least, he was physically able to carry out his boasts. These, with the further facts that he assumed a fighting attitude when approached by Smith, and that when Many Fingers stepped back after receiving the blows complained of, no further attempt was made by Smith to strike him, convinces me after consulting a number of authorities on this point
that the force used was not under the circumstances unreasonable.

For the reasons submitted the appeal will be allowed with costs and the conviction quashed and set aside with costs."

This case when brought before police magistrate Low at Cardston, was handled by the R.C.M.P. police at that point. This judgment of Judge McDonald will now conclude this case.

May 29, 1928.

Dear Father Boys:

With reference to my letter of the 11th instant, concerning an increased per capita grant for the Blood Indian Residential School, I wish to inform you that on October 12th, last, Mr. Indian Agent Pugh was requested to have the Reverend Principal prepare a statement of the extraordinary expenses at the school and to forward this to the Reverend Father Guy. Our files do not show any record of this statement, so you will understand why an adjustment has not been made.

I have decided that a grant of $165 shall be allowed as from July first, last, and I have asked Mr. Ferrier to make the necessary adjustment. The Reverend Principal will receive a cheque for the arrears in the near future.

Yours very truly,

Duncan C. Scott
Deputy Superintendent General.

Dear Father Beys:

In reply to the Reverend Father Therien's letter from Lachine, with reference to live stock and agricultural equipment at the Blood and Peigan Schools, I have to state that the Reverend Sisters should not take any away without my approval. As the Department has financed these schools for many years, I believe the stock and equipment should be considered school property.

Yours very truly,

Duncan C. Scott
Deputy Superintendent General.

Lachine, May 29th, 1928.

The Honorable Duncan Scott
Deputy Minister of Indian Affairs.
Ottawa.

Honorable and Dear Sir,

Reverend Father Beyes to whom I had transmitted by mail your decisions on different matters treated between you and I in our interview in Ottawa has written to me and in his letter he says:

"Please assure Mr. Scott of my deep appreciation for the good reception he has given you and of my earnest desire to do all I can to cooperate with him in all things."

Re Agnes Crop Eared Wolf: Father Beyes says: "I am quite willing not to press the point and considering that Mr. Scott has always been very fair to all concerned, we shall accept his decision in the matter."

Re The stock of the Sisters used at present by the schools in the Peigan and Blood reserves, I think I was misunderstood. I did not insist on the Department buying said stock; but as the Rev. Sisters may insist and in fact insist on taking away what really belongs to them, and we, not being really in a position to buy or replace same, we ask the Department to supply the said schools at least with the most necessary items so that the schools may proceed normally when the sisters take away what belongs to them. Otherwise it would be impossible for us to run those schools!

My dear Mr. Scott, Re the above item I believe that Father Beyes' contention is fair. In fact those schools up to lately were under the control of the sisters as far as financial side is concerned. The Oblates taking now the absolute control of the school are in the same position as those other schools which in the beginning are provided by the Department for the most necessary items to go on with the running of the school such as: Horses, cows, agricultural implements &c.

In a word, the sisters abandoning the running of the school take away with what belong to them and the Oblates taking charge of the
The school have nothing to start with and appeal to the Department to get what is given to the other schools being in the same financial circumstances.

I am leaving for the west next Sunday, should you favor me with an answer, please be kind enough to send it to the R.C. Rectory, Lachine. On my behalf let me offer you my most sincere thanks for your kind reception and you may rest assured of my entire cooperation in anything that might be for the good of the Department and the benefit of the Indians.

Believe me Honorable and dear Sir,

Your's truly,

J.A. Thivierge

R.C. Rectory, Lachine
June 22nd, 1928.

Dear Father Beys,

With reference to our previous correspondence on the subject of educational affairs on the Blood reserve, I have to inform you that I have noted the result of the case which arose out of the disciplinary measures used by an employee of the Blood Roman Catholic School. Notwithstanding the acquittal of Mr. Smith I am constrained to say that I am strongly opposed to punishment carried out by this method and I should hope that it will be the last occasion on which such an incident would occur. If there is any recurrence I should insist immediately upon the discharge of the offending official. In the present instance I may even yet decide that that is the best course, but the matter will be held in abeyance. I should like you to convey to the principal my strong disapproval of Mr. Smith's conduct.

When I was on the Blood reserve last summer I endeavoured to moderate the feeling which exists on the reserve with reference to recruiting pupils and I asked both principals to make an effort to accommodate themselves to the circumstances, and before pupils were drafted to the schools, to discuss the matter with the Indian agent in order that no difficulties should arise. I asked Mr. Pugh to use his best endeavours to satisfy the principals and it was understood that all matters should be freely

Very Rev. J. B. Beys, O.M.I.,
Oblate Fathers' Provincial House,
10188 107th St.,
Edmonton, Alta.
discussed between these three gentlemen. I think if my suggestions were followed we should have less trouble. I know that you will join me in the wish that these difficulties should moderate and entirely disappear.

With very kindest regards, I am,

Yours faithfully,

[Signature]

Deputy Superintendent General.
Sir,

I beg to advise that under date of Oct. 9th, Mr. G.E.A. Rice of Lethbridge, who defended Edwin Smith in the complaint of Many Fingers versus Edwin Smith, has advised that His Honor Judge MacDonald has fixed the costs in this trial and appeal at $63.45, and has ordered Many Fingers to pay the same.

The afore-mentioned has written asking me to collect and remit this amount, and I find this will inflict somewhat of a hardship on Many Fingers, having already paid out $50.00 to the lawyer who took the case for him, and other costs amounting to some $30.00.

I presume that I shall be held responsible for this payment if Many Fingers refuses to pay. The Department will no doubt understand this man's feelings in regard to this case, especially in view of the fact that the family are the most law-abiding people I have under my charge, and I personally feel very bad over the matter.

I should be glad to have advice in this matter.

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent.

EXTRACT FROM LETTER OF MR. J. E. PUGH, INDIAN AGENT, CARDSTON, ALTA., DATED DECEMBER 1, 1928., RELATIVE TO TRUANCY AT THE R. C. INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL ON THE BLOOD RESERVE.

When Sorrel Horse came before me he made the statement that he had been to see Father Ruaux, and asked him not to whip the boy when he brought him back, but Father Ruaux stated he would unless the Agent told him not to. If the statement is correct, it hardly seems fair to be burdened with that kind of statement and savors very much of placing me in the position of a go between. I deal with the Indians strictly according to the Act without reference to personal feelings, and when one gets a statement such as Big Sorrel Horse makes, I am forced to the admission that some tact is not being shown. I may say that last week I had another Indian make a similar complaint, and I feel that it makes a situation which is hard to handle, much more difficult.
January 2nd, 1929.

In connection with the relationship between the Indian Agent's Office, Blood Agency, and the Principals of the two residential schools in the Agency, particularly with regard to the question of returning truant pupils, see letter of December 19th, 1928, from Indian Commissioner Graham enclosing copy of a letter received from Mr. Agent Pugh. This correspondence is on File 15-103.
Ottawa, May 22, 1929.

Reverend Sir:

The Department is desirous of learning if the elder girls at the Blood Indian Residential School are being trained in milking cows. As most of the graduates of your school will return to reserves that are largely farming communities, it is very important that the girls be fully competent in this particular. The Department expects that the elder girls, under proper supervision, will be given a course of instruction in milking, and I shall be pleased to learn that suitable arrangements have been made.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean
