NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

4. The Return must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

Ottawa, 30th Dec. 1897

Secy
Dept. of Indian Affairs
Ottawa,

Dear Sir,

Herewith please find enclosed vouchers for which receipt no. $356.98 is attached.

Truly yours,
[Signature]

Enclo.
Office of the BLOOD AGENCY. Indian Agency,

[Signature]

SIR:

I have the honour to enclose herewith Vouchers Nos. 3622, amounting to $165.05.

This expenditure was authorized by [signature].

I have the honour to be,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

The Secretary.

Indian Affairs, Ottawa.
Memorandum for the Secretary.

I beg to present herewith certain Vouchers approved by the Indian Agent on the Blood Reserve, for freighting and wages in connection with work on the new Roman Catholic Boarding School on the Blood Reserve. There is an item in the Estimates of $1200.00 to provide for the addition, for School purposes, to the Hospital on this Reserve. I observe from the note on these Vouchers that the expenditure was authorized by the Indian Commissioner, on the 17th November 1897. The expenditure has not received the sanction of the Department, and certain arrangements made by the Commissioner with reference to the school in Treaty 7 have been disapproved by the Department (see File 118153/5 A), although the expenditure on the Blood Reserve was not specially included in this disapproval, and it does not appear from the Commissioner's correspondence to have fallen within the arrangement he made with the Bishop. The Union Bank, which cashed these Vouchers naturally expects payment, but I do not see how we can pay without further explanations.

8th January, 1898.

Accountant.
Ottawa, 19th January, 1888.

Sir,

I beg to acknowledge the receipt of the favourable letter from you, dated January 15th, in which you state that you have been obliged to make an advance to the Indians until now. The expenditure in question was incurred without Departmental authority, and the amount is not, I am sorry to say, any appropriation to which the outlay could be properly charged, and I am therefore obliged to return the advance to you.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

The Manager,
The Union Bank,
Ottawa.

Dear Mr. Forget,

I have not heard yet that you have authorized to issue vouchers for the building expenses of the H.M. Boarding School or the Blood Reserve out of the sum of $1000.00 voted for the purpose. I know that, of late, the men working there have been asking for their wages.

I hope that all the matter is settled by this time, but I would be glad to be informed that payment has been begun.

I have the honour to be,

Smile J. LePage, O.M.I.,

MEMORANDUM FOR THE ASSISTANT SECRETARY.

I can add very little on the subject of the expenditure on the Roman Catholic Boarding School on the Blood Reserve to what is said in my memorandum of January 8th. In considering payment of these vouchers the points to be emphasized are the absence of authority for the expenditure and the wording of the amount in the detailed estimates. If the former point can be overlooked and the latter explained by the Commissioner, (as it is not evident to the Department what connection the Hospital has with the school,) the vouchers might be paid. For my part I do not think the minister's decision with reference to the school on the Peigan Reserve affects this case very materially.

The reason that the vouchers were returned to the Bank was that the Branch of the Union Bank here urged us to either pay them or to return them to the Bank. According to their request we did the latter. This Bank not being accustomed to do business with the department seems to consider these vouchers as ordinary matter for collection.

Accountant.

Feb'y 4th, '98.

To D. Laird Esq.,
Indian Commissioner,
Winnipeg.

Dear Sir,

Last August I requested the Commissioner to utilize the unexpended grant towards purchasing furniture, as stoves, bedsteads etc for the Boarding School and in answer, August 29/98, No.122/73 I have been informed that this request was to be made some time in January or February.

I take the liberty to call your attention on that point. The Boarding School being the property of the Indian Department it seems to me that the furniture and dependences must be in the same case. Many things are needed for starting such an institution, and our resources are very small yet.

If you agree to expend the whole or part of the unexpended sum, on notification I will supply your Department with a list of the articles required.

Expecting a satisfactory answer,

Yours &c., &c.,
J. Riou, O.M.I.
Principal.

EVACHE DE ST-ALBERT.
Alberta, Canada.
Calgary March 9/99.

D. Laird Esq.
Indian Commissioner,
Winnipeg.

Dear Sir,

Allow me to call your attention to the indebtedness incurred in order to complete the Catholic Boarding School on the Blood Reserve. There is a sum of about $1300.00 due to Peter McLaren's Lumber Mill, in Macleod, outside of the $500.00 advanced by the Mission and which we expect shall be refunded afterwards.

I would respectfully ask that appropriation be made in the supplementary estimates, to pay off, as soon as possible, the amount due to Mr. McLaren. Application has been made by Rev. Father Riou, Principal of the School, on this subject, and I strongly recommend it to your consideration.

This can be done the more easily that at this school, and many other Boarding Schools as well, the number of children authorized is far from being completed and cannot be completed before the expiration of the fiscal year.

Hoping that you will kindly look into the matter and authorize the payment of said amount.

I have the honour &c.

Emile J. Legal. Bp.of Pogla.
Coadj. of St Albert.
Blood Reserve.

March 11/99.

To D. Laird Esq.
Indian Commr.,
Winnipeg.

Dear Sir,

I have the honour to inform you that I sent through Indian Agent's Office to your Department the bill of lumber against the Roman Catholic Boarding School. Will you kindly pay on it the balance of the $200 dollars voted for the actual fiscal year. That will leave a debt of $100 dollars about, plus $500 dollars paid by the R.R.Sisters of Charity last summer to Mr. McLaren, or a total of $600 dollars.

Would you kindly put that sum in your supplementary estimates in favour of the Roman Catholic Boarding School Blood Reserve, or if there is no possibility for it, divide the said sum between the supplementary estimate of this year and the estimates for the next fiscal year.

Hoping that you will do this with the best of your experience,

I am, dear Sir,

Sincerely yours,

J. Riou, O.M.I.

Sir,

I have been requested by the principal of this school to write you & ask if there is any possibility of any funds being made available for repairs.

I visited the school a few days ago & some of the floors are certainly in a dangerous condition & it was thought that if funds could be obtained to put in some new flooring, the work could be done during the holiday season, which is now coming on.

There is also considerable painting to be done & to do the work that is absolutely necessary to be done to render the building habitable, the least amount that could be got along with would be $250.00.

To do the work properly would entail a much larger outlay, but having the department's policy of retrenchment in mind I would ask that the above sum of $250.00 be granted.

I am,
Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent.

For sanitary reasons the R. C. Boarding School should have installed two drinking fountains.
Sir,

In reply to your letter of 30th, ultimo I beg to supply further particulars with regard to the work I proposed to have done at the R.C School.

There will require to be laid about a thousand feet of new flooring, which will cost for flat grain flooring, $5.00 per ft. It will cost about the same amount to lay this flooring as the old floor will have to be torn up & there is quite a lot of patching to do, which takes more time than the laying of an absolutely new floor.

There are eight floors which require to be painted with two coats of paint & the estimated requirements for this is eighteen gallons. The estimated requirements for painting ceiling is four gallons & for the walls of one room & stairway another two gallons.

This makes a total of twenty-two gallons, which at say $5.00 per gallon will amount to $120.00 & in addition to this $10.00 will be required for brushes.

The above figures total $240.00 & I allowed $10.00 more for contingencies which makes $250.00 the amount of my requisition.

I trust the above figures will enable you to arrive at a decision in the matter.

I am,

Your obedient Servant,

Indian Agent.

P.S. I might add that the Sisters will do the painting.

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Ottawa, July 28, 1919.

Memorandum—

Hon. Mr. Naishon,

The Estimates for the current fiscal year provide for the erection of a new Roman Catholic boarding school on the Peigan Indian reserve. In this connection I beg to draw your attention to an interchange of letters between Commissioner Graham and myself, particularly with reference to the boarding schools on the Blood and Peigan reserves. You will observe that Commissioner Graham agrees with the policy which I wished to establish in this matter, and I would ask your concurrence. I am so convinced of the reasonableness of this proposition that I think the Roman Catholic and Anglican Churches will have to meet our wishes, or else we should not incur any further capital expenditure for school buildings on these reserves.

Duncan C. Scott,

Deputy Superintendent General.
Ottawa, August 19, 1919.

Dear Canon Gould -

As you may be aware it is the policy of the Department to rebuild our industrial and boarding schools when necessary on more improved plans. Previous to 1914 we had an extensive plan outlined looking forward several years under which we were to replace in order of necessity, as far as possible, buildings considered no longer fit for the purpose which they were serving. The war, however, intervened and we were obliged from economical reasons to curtail very largely our building schemes.

On the list for rebuilding were the Victoria Home and the Roman Catholic school building on the Pelican Reserve, and I had planned later to renew both the Roman Catholic and Church of England buildings on the Blood Reserve. However, owing to the necessity of strict retrenchment these matters have been reconsidered and it has been decided that four schools on these two reserves are not necessary; the construction and maintenance thereof being an uncolled burden both on the Government and the church authorities. It has been decided that one school for each denomination situated at the most convenient points should provide sufficient accommodation for the education of the children of the reserves in Southern Alberta.

I have already informed His Lordship Bishop Locally accordingly, and I am now writing to apprise you of the decision of the Department, arrived at, as said above, after due consideration.

Yours very truly,

Duncan C. Scott,
Deputy Superintendent General.

Rev. Canon S. Gould, M.D.,
General Secretary of the Missionary Society of the Church of England,
151 Confederation Life Building,
Toronto, Ont.

Extract from Agent's Report on the Blood R. C. Boarding School for the month of January, 1920. Original on 180148-7

We are greatly in need of a more modern school building where the children could be kept under better sanitary conditions; and the thing most noticeable to me is how the Sisters can keep the school looking as well as they do under present conditions.

(Sgd.) J. E. Ostrander,
Agent.
R.C. Boarding School, Stand-Off, March 1st, 1920.

To Mr. W.J. Ostrander, Agent,
Blood Reserve.

Dear Sir,

We have decided to buy the second hand baking-oven as you advised us to do, although we knew that such an expense would be above our means in the present circumstances, but it was a matter of urgent necessity, so we ask you to be kind enough to use your influence with the Indian Department to come to our assistance in the purchase and installation of this oven which will amount to, at least, $200.00 two hundred dollars.

We have no doubt that if our reasons for buying this oven were made known to the Indian Department, they would willingly come to our assistance. As you know the personnel of the School is about seventy-five, who consume an average of about eight sacks of flour per week, we had to bake that amount of bread on a common kitchen range, besides the rest of the cooking, so that we had to bake from four o'clock in the morning until nine o'clock in the evening, to meet the requirements of the school, besides the inconvenience of the excessive heat in the kitchen during the summer season which is enough to impair the health of any person.

Trusting that you will take this in consideration and that you will interest the Indian Department in our favour,

I remain,

Very sincerely yours,

[Signature]

Principal
Sir,

I beg to enclose herewith a letter I have received from the Reverend Father Runaux, Principal of the R.C. School on the Reserve.

The Father has been trying for some time to get a bake oven for the school & some few weeks ago we got in touch with a man who had one for sale & it was decided to buy it, as it had only been in use a very short time & was splendid value at the price $100.00.

On my periodical visits to the school I have frequently remarked the excessive heat in & in the neighbourhood of the kitchen in the school, as also the tired look of the Sisters & older girls who seemed to be continually baking & wondered how they stood it & the Father advised me that they kept changing them around from day to day, as it was the only way they could stand it.

Father Runaux asks for $200.00 to pay for the oven & the installation of the same & I think if the Department can see their way to grant his request, I think the money will be well spent as I am satisfied that baking under the present conditions is far from being beneficial to the health, especially of the young girls employed.

The installation would consist of the building of a lean-to, against the present kitchen, the bedding of the oven in cement &c & generally fitting up the oven for use.

Trusting that this application may receive your favorable consideration,

Your obedient servant,

The Secretary

Indian Agent.
Ottawa, March 12, 1920

Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 4th instant, requesting that a grant be provided to reimburse the Principal of the Blood Roman Catholic Boarding School to the extent of $100.00 in the purchase of a bake oven and also $100.00 to pay for the installation of the same, and enclosing a communication from the principal regarding the matter.

In reply I beg to say that in view of the reasons given by the principal for the need of this oven, the Department will provide a grant not to exceed a total of $200.00 to cover the cost of the oven and the installation of the same. You will be good enough to inform the principal accordingly, and you may arrange to have the work of building a lean-to and the bedding of the oven in cement and any other work required to complete the installation.

In the purchase of any material required for the installation of the oven you will be guided by the requirements of the War Purchasing Commission, as set forth in circular letter of the 25th of February last.

You should forward properly certified vouchers, in duplicate, covering the expenditure incurred to the extent of the amount allowed as stated above.

Your obedient servant

J. E. Ostrander, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
MacLeod, Alta.

Memorandum:

R.C. Boarding School, Stand-Off, May 27th, 1920.

538403

To Duncan Scott, Deputy Minister,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Honourable Sir,

I feel that I must apologize for not having thanked you sooner for the generous grant of $200.00 which has purchased for us a galvanized iron baking oven. I have been absent from my desk every day lately on account of the spring work, but my thanks are nevertheless the more hearty.

This oven is a very convenient acquisition for our school, in fact, it was of an absolute necessity, as stated to you before, and the staff of the school is in measure to appreciate it at its real value for commodity, economy of time and fuel.

In my own name, and in the name of the staff of the R.C. Boarding School Blood Reserve, I pray you, Honourable Sir, to accept the expression of our deep gratitude.

Yours truly,

[Signature]
principal
Superintendent General of Indian Affairs, Canada.

Ottawa, July 25th, 1921.

Memorandum:

Mr. J. D. McLean -

I beg to refer you to your memorandum of the 19th instant regarding certain recommendations made in a communication addressed to Bishop McNally by Rev. Father Riou, Principal of the Crowfoot Boarding School on the Blackfoot reserve.

The Minister has read your memorandum and with reference to paragraph No. 4 he instructs that some sort of cheap implement shed should be built for the use of the Boarding School.

With reference to the last paragraph of your memorandum the Minister instructs that arrangements be made at once to install one bath in the Roman Catholic School on the Blood Reserve.

Kindly see that the Minister's instructions in the above connection are carried out as soon as possible.

Sgd. J. C. Caldwell,
Private Secretary.

Memorandum,-

Hon. Sir James Lougheed.

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your memorandum of the 15th instant, inclosing a communication addressed to you by Reverend Father Riou, Principal of the Crowfoot boarding school, located on the Blackfoot reserve. I shall reply to the different matters in the order in which they are presented by the Reverend Father:

Regarding the installation of baths and sanitary arrangements at the Roman Catholic School on the Blood reserve, concerning which His Lordship Bishop McNally spoke to the Minister, this is a very old building, almost beyond all usefulness for the purpose of a boarding school. Just at the present time, we are concluding the purchase of a lot near Clareholm, on which it is proposed to erect a school, to be used jointly for the Catholic children of the Blood and Peigan reserves. It is probable that, if funds are available, we will go ahead with this work next year, and, in view of this, it is not considered advisable to spend very much on the old school building, either by way of repairs or equipment. We will, however, make inquiries, and see if some bath tubs could be installed, which might be used when equipping the new school. We have not the data before us to enable us to decide that here.

J. D. McLean.
Acting Deputy Supt. General.
Sir:

I wish to inform you that it was brought to my attention that the furnaces in the Roman Catholic school on the Blood Reserve, are in very poor shape, and as the grates were burned out they were unable to put on fires. I therefore instructed the Agent to purchase grates and a few minor repairs, and he intends to have the Engineers, who are running the threshing outfit on the Reserve, do the repairs. This will do away with the necessity of bringing in a man from outside to do the work.

I trust my action in this matter will meet with the approval of the Department.

Your obedient servant,

W.M. Graham
Indian Commissioner.

The Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Sir,

In my duties, and, as acting Medical Officer to the Indians I feel also that I would be negligent in my duties did I not bring this matter to the attention of the proper authorities. What to do is another question. The material has no right to be dumped into the river, for this river forms the source of water supply for many people below.

I think the best solution of the problem would be to have a modified settling tank built, and the sewage allowed to flow into this, this tank to be below the ground and covered. And most important of all, have it some little distance away from the river, so that the water supply both for the Mission and for others will not be contaminated. It is a fact that sewage purifies itself by filtration, and if the reservoir is sufficiently far away from the river, the gradual seeping and catching of the hole by filtration will turn the effluent into the river, purified, so that no harm will result.

This is a matter which should be taken up at once and in the meantime, I would discourage as far as possible the usage of the present system, and take the precaution to have a plentiful supply of Chloride of Lime on hand, for use there, and see that it is freely used.

Yours truly,

Cpl. Alan H. M. Kennedy.

Sir—

In my duties, and as acting Medical Officer to the Indians I feel also that I would be negligent in my duties did I not bring this matter to the attention of the proper authorities; not to do so is another question. The material has no right to be dumped into the river, for this river forms the source of water supply for many people below. I think the best solution of the problem would be to have a modified septic tank built, and the sewage allowed to flow into such a tank to be below the ground and covered and most important of all, have it some little distance away from the river, so that the water supply both for the mission and for others will not be contaminated. It is a fact that sewage purifies itself by filtration, and if this reservoir is sufficiently far away from the river, the gradual seepage and applying of the soil by filtration will turn the effluent into the river, purified, so that no harm will result.

This is a matter which should be taken up at once and in the meantime, I would discourage as far as possible the usage of the present system, and take the precaution to have a plentiful supply of Chloride of Lime on hand, for use there, and see that it is freely used.

Yours truly,

Sgd. Alan H. N. Kennedy.

Dear Sir,

While out at the Hospital at Stand Off on Sunday I had occasion to go over to the School, and while there, took the opportunity to inspect the Sanitary arrangements. I do not know whether you are aware of the conditions there or not, but I was absolutely amazed to find them as they were, and under the existing conditions, it is the biggest surprise to me that there has not been a very large outbreak of either Typhoid Fever or Diptheria, coming from the School.

I saw Baths and sinks in the building and naturally asked where the outlet of them was, and it was taken for granted that the dirty water is allowed to run from the building to a depression in the ground over a small hill, not twenty-five yards from the back door of the Institution. Here this dirty water lies, until washed away by what is the most beautiful location for the breeding of all kinds of germs, practically outside the Kitchen door, where flies abound. These flies which are the proven carriers of Typhoid germs alternate between the stinking pool of dirty water and the refuse, and the fact that is being prepared for the Indian children, and the attendants.

As far as I could see there was no attempt made to keep this pool covered, or even disinfected such as Chloride of Lime thrown about. It is really one of the most glaring cases of insanitation that I have come across, and I am disgrace not only to the school, but to the Indian Department as well. On making enquiries I found that this condition has been going on for some considerable time, and I can quite believe that in the summer-time the smell from it is pretty near unbearable.

Not only is this pool unsanitary for the reason that I have mentioned, but the point also has to be taken that this place is not very far from the river, the source of their water supply, and the water is taken in below this cesspool. I don't quite know the slope of the land there, but it is not very hard to imagine the escape from this pool seeping into the water supply, with the added dangers from this source. How they have escaped a serious epidemic of Typhoid there, under the existing conditions, is more than I can understand.

Something will have to be done about this at once or the Indian Department will be very negligent in its
Sir,

I beg to enclose herewith, copy of a letter I have received from Dr Kennedy, Acting Medical Officer for this Reserve, in regard to the sanitary conditions at the Roman Catholic Mission.

What the doctor says in regard to conditions is just about right & if it would be the intention of the Department to alleviate these conditions in view of the fact that under the Department's authority a bath tub is being installed at the school, for which drainage will be necessary, the simplest way would be to connect the drain from the sink with the one from the bath & carry this drain to a cesspit over towards the river. About two hundred feet of 6" tile would be necessary for this undertaking, or say 4" pipe, which costs about thirty cents per foot in Calgary.

I shall be glad if the Department will authorise me to have this very necessary work attended to, or may I take it that the authority given to install a bath-tub would cover the cost of necessary drainage. If it is a matter of cost, there is a good bath-tub in my house which I cannot make use of, on account of there being no water supply & no heating arrangements sufficient to keep an upstairs cistern from freezing. This tub could be taken out & transported to the school, in which case the cost of a new tub would be saved & I can get along better without a hot plunge than the Indian children can with typhoid.

Your Obedient Servant,

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs, Indian Agent.

Ottawa, Canada.
Ottawa, December 13th, 1931.

Dear Sir,

Replying to your letter of the 21st ult., with reference to the drainage required for the baths at the Roman Catholic School, I beg to advise you that you may have a 4" tile drain installed and connected with the drain from the sink and carried to a cess-pool approximately 200' from the building.

In purchasing the 4" tile drain, competitive prices should be obtained and tile purchased from the firm quoting the lowest price.

Your obedient servant,

(J. D. McLean)
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

J. T. Faunt, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Macleod, Alta.

Memorandum:

Mr. Scott:

Concerning the attached communication from the Rev. Father Guy, I have to inform you that the Rev. Father Grandin, and others, have drawn our attention from time to time to the incomplete condition of the Crowfoot Boarding School building. When we were preparing the supplementary Estimates for this year there was brought to our attention the extreme desirability of interior decorating and plastering. The Rev. Fathers Grandin and Guy now strongly urge the brick veneering of the building, before the interior alterations are carried out.

The main building was erected in 1914, and was so constructed that brick veneering could be done later. At the time of my visit in August of last year, it was drawn to my attention that the proposed veneering should be done as soon as possible.

In the supplementary Estimates for 1922-23, $6,000.00 is voted for repairs to the Crowfoot Boarding School.

Associated with this question is the poor condition of the institutions under the R.C. Church on the Blood and Peigan reserves. The Crowfoot and Blood buildings belong to this Department and the Peigan, to the church. Because of the uncertain plans concerning R.C. Indian educational work in Southern Alberta (Clarke's Int?) I hesitate to make a recommendation regarding the old buildings on the Blood and Peigan.

The Crowfoot Boarding school on the Blackfoot is modern and has been admirably cared for, and I would recommend that the brick veneering be done this year. Because of the large capital and interest moneys of the Blackfoot band, I respectfully ask your opinion regarding the possibility of securing, from this source, the necessary funds over and above the $6,000.00 budget-to-be.

Sept. of Indian Education.
Mr. Duncan C. Scott,
Deputy Superintendent General,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

My dear Mr. Scott:

As already mentioned to you Rev. Fr Grandin is asking me to apply to the Department for very urgent repairs at the Blood Indian School.

Last year, he personally asked from you that these repairs be done and I have included a similar request in view of the estimates. It seems that as the future of the school is uncertain that the Department hesitates to do very necessary repairs. I must say in the name of Rev. Fr Grandin that it is impossible for the staff and children to spend another winter under such trying circumstances. I would therefore ask your kind and prompt attention to this matter.

Believe me

Yours truly,

[Signature]

Indian Affairs - School Files (AG 10, Volume 6743, File 720-5, part 2)
Ottawa, May 31, 1922.

Dear Father Guy:

I wish to assure you that I have given considerable thought to the questions arising out of your three communications of the 23rd instant, referring to the needs of the Crowfoot, Blood and Peigan Roman Catholic Boarding Schools. The plans for future education of Roman Catholic Indian children in the southern part of Alberta are somewhat undermined at present; but I have come to the conclusion that there should be no cessation in our efforts to properly house the children at present admitted to residential schools.

The Crowfoot Boarding School on the Blackfoot Reserve is relatively a new building and has been admirably cared for. I will instruct Mr. Commissioner Graham, of Regina, to make overtures as soon as possible to the Indian band with a view to having them vote the funds necessary for the brick veneering of the exterior. I am hopeful that our efforts in this connection will be successful.

I have learned, with regret, that the Rev. Father Grandin states it is impossible for the staffs and children to spend another winter in the Blood and Peigan Roman Catholic Residential Schools. Mr. Ferrier reports that the buildings are in poor condition, and I am prepared to ask the Minister for the necessary authority to spend $1500.00 each on the Peigan and Blood schools. If the Minister O.K.'s the expenditure, I will ask you to instruct the Rev. Father Grandin and the principals to communicate, concerning the necessary repairs, direct with Mr. Commissioner Graham, under whose direction the work will be carried out.

Yours very truly,

Duncan C. Scott
Deputy Superintendent General.

Rev. Jos. Guy, O.M.I.,
University of Ottawa,
Ottawa, Ont.
R. C. Boarding School, Stand Off, May 4th 1922.

Mr J. T. Gaunt. Agent.

Blood Reserve.

Dear sir,

Repairs have been done on our school during the past winter for which I must say we are most grateful. One thing however has been overlooked; our kitchen range is in the poorest of condition, as old as the building itself; the firepot and top part of the stove have been renewed several times, and at the present time the whole range is in such a bad condition and worn out that it would be useless to spend money for repairs on it, besides it would be impossible to affix to it attachments for hot water system, bath tubs have been installed in the school but having no water system every Saturday we are obliged to heat water at the wash house and carry it with pails to the dormitories for the children's baths, which is very inconvenient.

Of course you know the range having seen it several times, consequently, I would ask you to use your influence with the Indian department, to obtain a new one for us, as our financial standing will not allow us to meet the expense of buying one ourselves.

I remain Sir, Dear Sir,

Respectfully Yours,

Sgd. F. Ruaux.
Sir,

I beg to enclose herewith copy of a letter received by me from Father Ruaux, Principal of the R. C. School, in which he asks that I use my influence with you with a view to a new range being installed at the school.

As he says, the range is in a very delapidated condition & altogether unfit for the duties which it is supposed to perform & if at all possible I would suggest that something be done by way of replacing the range.

I had thought that a great many of the hotels in this part of the country having closed up since prohibition went into effect, a good second hand range might very readily be picked up « I shall be glad to have your authority to make enquiries with a view to the purchase of such a range.

Your obedient Servant,

Indian Agent.

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Canada.
OTTAWA, June 9th, 1922.

Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 28th ultimo, enclosing copy of a communication from the Principal of the Blood R.C. Boarding School in which he requests that a new kitchen range be supplied for the use of the school.

In reply I beg to say that the Department will approve of the purchase of a range of the size and capacity required for the use of this school. You may make enquiry with a view to the purchase of a good second-hand range, but if you are unable to obtain such, it will then be necessary to obtain competitive prices from a number of dealers in making the purchase of a new range. No undue expenditure should be incurred and the range, while serviceable and of a satisfactory type, should be purchased as cheaply as possible.

You will be good enough to forward properly certified vouchers, in duplicate, covering the expenditure incurred, and, if it is not possible for you to obtain a second-hand range, it will be necessary, in submitting vouchers for the purchase of a new range, to attach a memorandum showing the names of the firms asked to quote and the prices quoted.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

J. T. Faunt, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Macleod, Alta.
Ottawa, May 31, 1922.

Memorandum.

Honorable Charles Stewart:

For some months I have consistently refused to expend funds on the Blood and Peigan Roman Catholic Residential Schools in Southern Alberta, because of the somewhat indefinite plans for the future of the Indian educational work under the auspices of that church in the district mentioned.

It has been brought to my attention that it will be impossible for the teachers and pupils to remain another winter, unless certain repairs are carried out at these two schools. The one on the Blood Reserve is government-owned and on the Peigan, church-owned.

The future for Roman Catholic Indian educational work in Southern Alberta is still unsettled, and this Department should see to the proper housing of our wards who are admitted to residence for the coming winter. I respectfully recommend that I be given authority to make repairs at the Blood and Peigan R. C. Boarding Schools to the amount of $1500 each.

Duncan C. Scott

Deputy Superintendent General.

June 15th, 1922.

Sir,

With reference to the urgent repairs required at the Blood R.C. Boarding School, I have to advise you that £1500 has been voted in this year's estimates to cover this work, and I would ask you to let me know the nature of the repairs which the Reverend principal wishes to have carried out.

In sending in your report kindly give as much detail as possible, and under no circumstances must the amount available be exceeded.

Your obedient servant,

(J.D. McLean),
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

Macleod, Alta.
with logs, but makes a request to be supplied with the necessary shingles. As near as I can make out about six thousand shingles will be required, probably a few more. He also makes a request to be supplied with two hundred feet of two inch iron pipe to carry water from the pump to the garden.

I would point out the urgency of granting this authority at once in order that the work can be carried on at the school during the vacation period, and I would see that all purchases are made in accordance with the Departments' regulations, that is as regards competition. The work should be done by day labour and I think can be safely handed over to the Indian Agent to carry out the instructions which are given to him.

There was an old shed situated on the site of the former residence of Doctor Steele which I handed over to the school to be used as a chicken house. They were glad to receive this and I was glad to know that it could be made good use of.

Yours very truly,

W.M. GRAHAM.
Indian Commissioner.
Dear Mr. Scott:

I have just returned from Alberta and while there I visited the Roman Catholic Boarding School on the Blood Reserve. As you know, this building is in very bad shape at the present time, and it seems to me that it is about impossible to carry on the work unless some extensive improvements are made. The Principal and the Nuns are very anxious that something be done at once, as the school is about to close for the summer vacation and in the interval the necessary work could be done.

I would recommend the following repairs be authorized: New floors for two play rooms. The size of these rooms 18x33. The floors are practically gone. New floor in kitchen, size 24x24. Thirty gallons of floor paint, five gallons of raw oil and one gallon of turpentine to be used in re-painting the floors and a supply of calcimine to renovate the walls, in the various rooms and dormitories. I find the kitchen range is in very bad shape and will have to be renewed. What is required is a kitchen range known as hotel size. I have hopes of obtaining this range from one of the Military Hospitals which was in existence at Regina last year. This range was handed over to the School Board who owned the building in which the Hospital was established. If I am successful in obtaining this range, it will not be necessary for the Department to supply one, but if not, I would be glad to have your authority to purchase a suitable range.

In addition to the above, the Father in charge of the School has erected a large stable with

Duncan C. Scott, Esq.,
Deputy Superintendent General,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.
MEMORANDUM.

Mr. Scott,

With reference to the attached letter from Mr. Graham, regarding the most urgent repairs required to the Blood Roman Catholic School, I beg to say that on June 15th, a letter was addressed to the Indian Agent, advising him that $1,500 had been voted in this year's estimates to cover the most urgent repairs needed at this school. He was asked to consult with the principal and advise the Department, giving as much details as possible of the necessary repairs, it being understood of course, that whatever work was done, the cost must not exceed $1,500.00.

Architect.
June 21st, 1922.

Dear Mr. Graham:

I have your letter of the 17th instant, No. 403-14, reporting on the present condition of the Blood R.C. Boarding School, and recommending that the repairs enumerated by you be carried out.

In reply I have to inform you that the Minister has approved of an expenditure not to exceed $1500 in having the most urgent repairs required at this school carried out. Previous to the receipt of your letter, we communicated with Mr. Agent Faunt and requested him to let the Department know the nature of the repairs which the Reverend Principal desired to have done this summer. A copy of this letter is enclosed herewith for your information. You may communicate with the Agent and inform him of the action you desire taken regarding these repairs.

The repairs enumerated by you in your letter, and which you recommended be undertaken, should be considered in connection with the other items of the work which the Principal desires to have carried out, and the whole cost incurred in these repairs should not exceed the above authorized amount.

The work should be completed during the vacation period, and all purchases should be made in accordance with the requirements of the Purchasing Commission.

Yours very truly,

Duncan C. Scott

Deputy Superintendent General.

W. M. Graham, Esq.,
Indian Commissioner,
REGINA, SASK.
Dear Mr. Scott:

I wrote you yesterday regarding repairs and requirements for the Roman Catholic Boarding School on the Blood Reserve. In my letter I stated that I was in hopes of obtaining a suitable range for the institution through the Regina School Board, but I regret to say that I received word today to the effect that they did not feel disposed to hand the stove over, nor will they sell it.

I measured the stove in the School. It is six feet long with a fire box in the centre and two extensions on either side, without the hot water attachments. What we need is the same size stove with hot water attachments. If this can be bought from the Purchasing Commission direct, I would ask that it be done; however, if it is your desire that I purchase here through wholesale firms I can do so, perhaps it would be better to make the purchase from this office as the Companies have representatives here in the City.

Duncan C. Scott, Esq.,
Deputy Superintendent General,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.
In view of the fact that this particular kind of range is required, is it necessary to call for competitive prices.

Yours very truly,

W.M. Graham,
Indian Commissioner.
OTTAWA, June 26th, 1922.

Sir,

I have been directed to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 20th instant, No. 402-13, regarding the purchase of a range for the use of the Blood R.C. Indian Boarding School.

In this connection I beg to state that a communication was received from Mr. Agent Faunt, dated May 28th last, in which he directed the attention of the Department to the need of having a new range installed in this school. He stated that a good second-hand range might be obtained from one of the hotels which had been closed. He was informed that he could arrange for the purchase of a good second-hand range, but that, if he was unable to obtain such, he might, after obtaining competitive prices, purchase a new range.

It might be well for you to communicate with Mr. Faunt and ascertain what action has been taken by him to obtain a range, and, if he has not done anything in this matter, you may arrange for the purchase of a new range. Competitive prices should be obtained and the range should be purchased and installed at the lowest possible cost.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

W. M. Graham, Esq.,
Indian Commissioner,
Regina, Sask.

Reverend Sir,

The enclosed account from the Western School Supply Company, Regina, covering the cost of the Kindergarten tables and chairs and freight charges thereon, supplied for the use of the Blood Roman Catholic Boarding School, should be forwarded in duplicate.

In our letter of January 19th, last, to the above firm we requested them to forward you these accounts in duplicate with the receipt for the freight charges attached. We are again writing this firm to send you the duplicate account and the freight receipt. You should certify the duplicate in the same manner as the account returned herewith and the two copies of the account and the freight receipt should be forwarded to the Department. Ottawa, February 21, 1923.

Gentlemen,

One copy of your account, covering the cost of the Kindergarten tables and chairs and freight charges thereon, supplied by you for the use of the Blood Roman Catholic Boarding School, has been received from the principal.

In our letter of January 19th, last, ordering the above supplies, we requested that you forward the account in duplicate, together with receipts for the transportation charges, to the principal. We are unable to pay your account until we receive a duplicate and the receipt for the freight charges.

I have, therefore, to request that you will forward, as soon as possible, to Rev. R. Rusux, O.M.I., Principal, Blood Roman Catholic Boarding School, Standoff, Alta., another copy of your account and the receipt for the freight charges paid by you.

It is necessary that these accounts be certified by the principal who has been requested to forward the same to the Department as soon as he receives them from you.

Kindly give this matter your early attention.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.
